content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												Having cut my teeth on hundreds and hundreds of hours of Heroes 3 and Heroes 5, I really wanted to like this one.  It looks great, no doubt, but I'm afraid the magic is gone.  Enemy AI cheats to a game-breaking extent, so the only way to really experience this properly is to only play with other people.  Unfortunately, that's not generally desirable or workable online, due to UPlay's instability and the general unreliability of anonymous players in general, and 1v1 hotseat (or the like) is itself pretty limited and unsatisfying.  I miss the days of playing cooperatively with one or two other human players against the AI.The mechanics have also become problematically distorted, leading to too many unwinnable games where the growth of map creeps outpace your own troop production, or how suffering even incidental losses in too many map skirmishes can permanently doom your long-term war effort.  The idea of local forts/castles serving as the control point for local resource generators in the area was kind of nifty, and I could be okay with that depending on how it was implemented, but it feels too much like everything that formerly made this series great (particularly in HoMM3) has been gradually stretched, squashed, and otherwise mashed into some cheap imitation of its former glory.  GIve this one a pass and go play Heroes 3 or 5, stat!

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												This is a fun, turn based Strategy RPG focusing on controlling an Empire and the Heroes that you recruit. (CATEGORY) "Poor/Sub-Par/Average/Great/Superb" 1-5/5 - Description(OVERALL)- My personal rating for this game is 85%. My average rating for this is 71% (3.5/5)(GAMEPLAY)  "Superb" 5/5 - Battles are turn based tactics using a grid system, similar to games like Final Fantasy Tactics, Poxnora, Disgaea, Ogre Tactics, etc. Each turn you aquire resources depending on what mines/ect you've captured, and can spend those resources to upgrade your town(s). Your Heroes gain levels, and new abilities which are both passive, affecting the Army of Monsters you recruit at your town, or directly doing damage or providing some various effects (slowing down enemies, speeding yours up, summoning monsters to fight for you, etc). You end up fighting Neutral monsters that are stationary on the map, usually blocking your path as your armies are too weak (at first). Armies are formed from Monsters/Units that you pay to recruit (with gold) at your town/village. Each unit bought will represent a "Stack" of units. You have around 10 slots to have different types of creatures in your army, and you can have as many "Stacks" as you can afford / create to build up your forces. There are a huge variety of ways to play this game, all of which are really fun. Many elements of this game are comparable to a 4X game. (STORY)  "Sub-Par" 2/5 -There is a storymode to this game, and infact it is one of the best ways to get strong gear for your Hero. Gear aquired during those missions (and some other ways) allow you to make your Hero stronger, earlier, in any form of gameplay. The story isn't insanely good, but I found it to be very well done as far as being creative. Depending on what DLC you buy changes how much story you can access. This is one of the greater faults for the game. The story itself is something I like, however limiting it by DLC is not something that I favor. (Note, without some of the DLC (IE you bought Shades of Darkness, not the original) you will get a lot less content, which is why this is a 2/5)(GRAPHICS)  "Average" 3/5 - The graphics are quite good, but not amazing. There is enough going on in the world that it can draw you in, as a fantasy world. There are all sorts of odd buildings, and interactable objects. Exploration is one fun factor in the game (as there is Fog of War) and the graphics help tie in the feeling of exploration. Seeing the units in 3D during battle is always nice, and fun to watch (though if you have a slow-walking unit, try speeding up how fast your units move)(SOUND)  "Great" 4/5 - At first I was going to rate this a 3/5, but I realized that several of the songs in this game had gotten stuck in my head. Remembering that, it was a lot easier to rate this a 4/5. The Gameplay was addictive, and so is the music. Although it isn't anything over-the-top, or mind-blowing, it is still a fitting sound track. (ONLINE)  "Sub-Par" 2/5 - The games worst issue, by far. MMH VI has to be connected to the internet at all times to play the game. DRM-Stuff. This is a huge deterrant for most people, and thus have rated this section quite low. However on the flip side it has a great single player mode (which you still need to be connected to the internet to play) which you can setup your own matches against the NPC's and either destroy them, or be destroyed! It is a lot of fun learning tactics for certain maps, and for certain factions. (RE-PLAYABILITY) "Superb" 5/5 - This game is truly addictive. While I only have 40 hours in the game right now, it is because I haven't been able to re-install it and to get it working (with an issue others have had, a black screen) I haven't tried re-downloading and installing since I tried last. The game has a great sense of addictiveness to it. You earn new equipment to use on your Hero. Your hero gains new levels, and you can re-do it every match. You can play all sorts of different tactics, take your time or not, and generally, do what you want. (COST) "Average" 4/5 - This game costs either 30$ USD or 20$ USD (Depending on if you get the base game or Shades of Darkness) My review is based on Shades of Darkness. At 20$ USD, this is a steal of a game, as long as you don't mind staying connected to the internet. (OVERALL)- My personal rating for this game would likely be a 4/5. My average rating for this was a 3.5/5 or a 70%.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												I've mixed feelings about this game. Ever since spending countless hours playing Heroes of Might and Magic III and it's expansions/mods years ago,  I've been a fan. I love a good turn-based tactical combat based game. In fact, it may be my favorite genre. A strong strategy of collecting resources, helpful items and building powerful kingdoms backed by a solid story, good character dialogue, with outstanding art and soundtrack all mixed together, it's my opinion there is no topping this genre of game. Might and Magic: Heroes VI though falls short of legendary status for many reasons. Many avenues of this series have been simplified such as the resources, additions like the caravan options from HoMM IV and NPC monsters on the map being able to attack you during their turn if you are too close are missing. The story is nothing that held my interest and the dialogue happening in the pop-up screens was pretty horrible in many instances, and the in-game cutscene graphics are pretty generic. I did enjoy the map art and the soundtrack was okay. The gameplay is decent, though at many times not challenging. I had to crank up the difficulty to hard for any real strategy. On normal it can be difficult in the first few levels, but once you amass some powers/items/armies it's pretty much a steamroll. I played through 3 of the campaigns and towards the end of the 3rd I was getting bored and just selecting auto-battle and having minimal to no losses. I did like the inclusion of dynasty weapons, dynasty traits and having to open further slots and options by playing more and earning the achievement points. Again, there wasn't much of a challenge to the achievements other than just playing long enough to rack up enough kills/battles won without losses/ etc. Uplay is another barrier. Online activation to continue your game, if you do need/have to be offline you have to play a game started in offline mode.  I don't like to open my steam purchased game in two menus. Not a deal breaker for me, but annoying and unnecessary.I doubt I'll go back and play another full campaign. Perhaps, a random map here and there. Overall, it's just okay. Nothing spectatular that a turn-based strategy lover must have, but a worthy buy if you come across for cheap.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												It could just be that this is a bad entry in a good series or maybe I’m just not a Might and Magic fan but despite the amount of time I put in I don’t feel like I enjoyed it. The things that come back to me after not playing it for a while was the annoyance of having to be connected to the internet to play the game. Internet went out while you were playing? Too bad, you’ll have to continue your single player game later…Additionally, the game had a player progression system, a ‘Dynasty’, where you can collect heroes, weapons, and such. While nice the leveling was painfully slow, I never maxed out any of my weapons and you can see how many hours I put into it, which made it feel rather unrewarding.Lastly, I’ll just say that I personally don’t like over world strategy part of the game. The movement was annoying, especially since it’s best to keep all your troops in a single army so you’re prepared for anything. However, since there is almost never a single route an enemy army can sneak around and you’re hightailing it back to your cities to protect them before you have time to do the reverse. If you split up your army to cover your flank you don’t have enough troops to assault the enemy city.The combat was cool but half the time it was so highly dependent on pure numbers that it felt like if you lost a battle it wasn’t because you made a tactical error but that you should have managed your cities better and recruited more troops.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												If you are a fan of turn-based tactical games, then this is a great entry in the genre, and even a better entry in the M&M series than the others to date.  M&M: Heroes 5 managed to hold my interest for somewhere around 15 to 20 hours, while I have enjoyed this one for almost 250 hours at the time of writing this review.The game does become fairly repetitive after a while, but its repetitiveness was not enough to put me off the game.  I typically get somewhere between 30 minutes to 5 hours out of a game, while games that I particularly enjoy might go as high as 60 or 70.  There is usually only one games each year that will get me to put in more than 40 hours, let alone the time I have invested into this game.I do find the UPlay dependence a bit obnoxious, as it sometimes takes up to a minute to get past the "Checking for UPlay Updates" screen (this on the latest system w/ SSD, 32gb RAM, 100mbit internet connection, etc.)  I was also disconnected partway through a major battle due to UPlay going offline.  I found this part to be inexcusable - it had a connection, let it reassert itself when it can but don't kick me out of the game!

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												If you've played Heroes III, IV, or V, know that this game is better. Yes, even better than Heroes III. Balace is well done, each faction has abilities that make them distinct and fun to play, and the combat strategy becomes more customizable thanks to the skill trees that you can fill as your heroes level up. Campaigns are extensive - each takes about 20 hours to complete (I've only made it through two), and there are about five in the base game.The only probem with this game lies with Ubisoft's "Conflux," an always-on social application that you must be connected to in order to play. It isn't intrusive, but it does mean that you need an internet connection to play, and if your internet cuts out, the game boots you out - even if you're in the middle of a 15 minute castle seige - and you have to reload the last save when you reconnect. It's a ♥♥♥♥♥, but it's ony a problem if you have unreliable internet.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Personally I find this to be the best HoMM game since the 3rd, don't really get the bad rep it got which seems to be aimed mostly towards uplay rather than the game itself, it's a shame.Unlike HoMM 5 the maps aren't nearly as linear (which was my biggest issue with the 5th entry)Neither have I run into too many bugs other than the camera-bug which makes me unable to look around with my mouse and having to nagivate with the arrow-keys instead (only a reboot seems to fix this from my experience) but fortunately it doesn't occure too often. Unlike the 3rd one you don't have the whole RNG randomness of skills whenever a hero lvls up, instead you get this RPG-esque option to put out talent points into either Magic or Might. The balance doesn't seem to be all there neither, might is a far superior choice over magic from what i've seen and the factions seems to be a bit unbalanced as well. There are less resources to think about, etc. You can also not steal mines in the same way you could previously since they are all connected to the owner of the nearby town so it's a bit less micro-heavy than previously as well. For some this might be a big issue.While the overarching story might not be anything amazing (neither was any of the previous installment's stories) I still enjoyed the campaign a great deal, playing from the different perspectives of Duke Slava's children, one for each faction.And honestly if you are into the story that much I'd recommend going for the Might & Magic series instead.All in all, It's a fun game if you can look past the whole double-DRM thing and some changed core features such as less resources and how the whole territory-war works.

content:

												i've written a review for this game before you'll notice i dont have very many hours played on this game. here's the thing it requires uplay to play. i know it says that on the store page but i missed it. anyway that's why i dont have a lot of hours played on this marked on my steam account. now before you think i'm just a hater you should know i own every single heroes of might and magic game (yes including heroes of might and magic 1, where the black dragons were actually purple) as well as all of the expansions up to right before 6.i'm going to keep this short and then i'll have the long list after it all. DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. PERIOD. as a heroes of might and magic game it's ok, but this game is ABSOLUTELY UNDESERVING of your money. the bugs in this game are absolutely insane and numerous. i'll post a list from another forum at the end of this review but good god you have no idea how♥♥♥♥♥♥it is. if you think the bugs have been fixed since this game is a few years old NOPE they haven't. ubisoft announced that they were no longer patching homm 6, and as off that final patch nearly all of the bugs on this list still exist.i'm not going to get into why i hate the whole uplay always online ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t i listed off reasons why it's ♥♥♥♥ing♥♥♥♥♥♥in my other review of this game. but i've gotten past that i tried to give this game another shot while ignoring my hatred of that uplay ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and i find that i have to maintaint he boycott i've held since i first bought homm 6. i'm never ever buying another ubisoft game ever again. their customer service is♥♥♥♥♥♥ i mean damn near comcast♥♥♥♥♥♥ my uplay account was fairly inactive for about a year i went back to try this game again and suddenly this game doesn't show up in my games library in uplay anymore. ok no problem i'll resubmit the cd-key that steam gave me. uplay tells me hey that cd key is being used by another account. so i contact their customer support it took 3 weeks of back and forth to figure out that at some point uplay had a big update and somehow the email for my account has a typo in it's address instead of (myemail)@whatever.com a copy of my account at (myemail)@whatever.com was made except the copy was .comm with 2 m's. so i couldn't retrieve the password for that account or even change the password for it since whenever you try to do anything it sends an email to get it done. except no email exists where the .com has 2 mm's. the useless customer support couldn't fix it for weeks until they decided to just change the email on the cloned account and i had to get a new email attached to that account. so now all of my previous achievements games, rewards that i earned in hmm6 for my old uplay account isn't transferred over to my new one. nice.anyway that's my not so short experience with ubisoft CS and homm 6. now for the list of bugs some of these are minor inconviences, they range from crashes, that happen if you take too long a map (except it's not really that long, you basically have to rush the map or the game will perma crash on an exact game date), all the way to your hero being permanently fubared by having his magic power of a specific school reduced to 1, permanently no fix at all."- unequip any staff with a magic school affinity before you either save your game, or end your turn. otherwise, when you reload/start a new turn, it will PERMANENTLY SUBTRACT 5 points from your effective magic power for every day you leave it equipped. This is hidden; you won't see it in your stats sheet when you look at your magic power, but you WILL see it in how much damage your magic troops do, and how much damage your spells do (also affects summoning!). ruined two characters like that, and had to restart an entire campaign to fix it- In the 4th map of the stronghold campaign, in the first week, Airini's earth elemental spell produces fewer elementals when cast each successive day. So, on the first day it was 22, the second, 16, the third 12, 4th 9, 5th 6! Restarting the mission without using Batu's Totem does not result in the strange gradual reduction of earth skills. Conclusion: BATU'S TOTEM IS BUGGED- occasional bug: if you unequip and re-equip a set-artifact then the set-bonus stacks up- In the barbarian campain on map 2 it gets to month two and mid week the game crashes (solution: finish map quickly!)- It looks as though luck with Infernal is really bugged; almost like they take on the reverse of whatever luck they should have.When I am not playing Inferno, and I have a combat against inferno neutrals, they act with the value of luck MY troops have, not based on the luck value in their descriptions. When I play WITH inferno against other neutrals, my Inferno troops take on the luck value of the NEUTRALS, and are not anywhere close to the luck value stated in their description. When playing inferno, the description often shows me values of luck over 60% for my troops, yet if I am facing a group of neutrals with luck values of say, 7%, then that is what my troops will act with - I have measured this over 100 combats now. Interestingly, this does NOT apply when I am facing off against an enemy hero, in those battles, regardless of faction, luck values work normally.-Pathfinding skill is still broken (actually adds movement PENALTY, instead of bonus on hard terrain!). I assume it was fixed for the normal campaigns, but not the expansions?--improving scouting levels does not improve scouting range to any apparent extent.- Souldrinker's Lifeforce (or whatever it's called, gives +3% to health) works for both sides (not only for weapon holder, but also for his opponents).- "Anathema" (blood skill -haven might) instead of LOWERING enemy damage, actually RAISES it.- Set a game with "Aggressive AI", for example. Save the game and when you load it again, the difficulty is "normal" instead of "custom".- Sometimes, for no apparent reason, heroes simply stop earning reputation points.- bonuses from visiting weekly shrines are often lost on reloading a saved game- Buffs after wait command: general weird behavior - buffs expire differently in some cases, like buff->action won't have the same result as wait->buff->action. Especially annoying with guardian angel- Hourglass of Asha (special of Nec town) gave a -15 ini penalty to both teams, in field battle in AoC. Should be: neither. only in siege defense should it work!- On map wasting grounds decreases health and damage not for all enemy creatures, but also for yours too, if they're not undead. Do not know about city version - need to check it.- Inferno campaign, map 2: Increasing magic power levels does not increase damage for magic-damage based troops, nor does it increase damage for spells (possible solution: it seems unlikely, but this is also the only campaign I chose to start with the dynasty trait "fanatic")- - Cleave+morale+wait: if stack gets morale bonus, and with the second action gets a kill that activates cleave, then issuing the wait command will give the stack 2 more actions afterwards (total 4 actions in 1 turn: regular->half power->regular->regular. Not sure about if last one being regular, only happened few times. Maybe it's half power too). So in this case wait gives one extra move.- The Azkaal Inferno fight became impossible thanks to what I assume are bugs. First, Mark of Consumption doesn't actually increase ensuing fire damage. Second, the Ill Blood (frenzy) move doesn't work on enemies that are not adjacent to anyone (in the past, this would keep the enemy from moving for 2 turns). As a result, the fight went from insanely difficult to literally impossible.- Necromancy II does not work in Necro Campaign. This bug appears after every battle in the arena (for example, near the 2nd city on the 1st campaign map) by default necro hero (Anastasia).- To use the faction trait in a campaign, you have to have it selected from the start of the campaign. it doesn't work to add it after you have c

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												A fun, intuitive and challenging game, Heroes VI is my favourite in the series. The graphics are BEAUTIFUL and the real-time battle models look astounding. Battles are a mix of complicated turn-based, chess-like gameplay, with interesting, game-changing abilities. The maps are fun to explore and are filled with treasure and plenty of monsters to fight. One thing worth noting is the difficulty of the campaigns. The AI are smart and aggresive. So if you are are a fan of being  able to say, "I've finished this game, good luck at doing it yourself", then you will really enjoy this. Heroes VI is also great fun to play against friends. It features a hot-seat gametype which can be tedious if you don't like waiting for your slow friend, though the AI in Custom Game will be a worthy, oppenent in an actual player's stead. So, if you are a fan of expansive, challenging strategy games or enjoyed the other games in this series, this should be an memorable experience.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Where to begin?  Wierdly, I feel let down by this game.  That's even taking into consideration I picked this game up in the sale for 7.99 because at this moment that feels like about 7.99 more than I should have paid.Firstly, you need to open the game UPlayer - which doesnt work and will come up saying "uplay uplayer has stopped" everytime unless you run as an admin from outside steam - which then opens the game through Steam requiring both Steam and UPlayer to be open simultaneously to run the game which is a complete FARSE.Secondly, having played previous HoMM titles I wasn't expecting the wheel to be reinvented - in fact I bought the game specifically to quench my thirst for turn based fantasy.  I then go into the game open up the custom game option and find that you can't even so much as change your faction without going through the games dynasty system ( a system basically set up to milk cash out of online play) and nor can you change the faction of AI players at all.  This is in "custom" games.  After realising this I went back to the menu and the more I looked at the game and it's features the more I felt that it didn't look like a game anymore, it looked like a F2P app with in game purchases.  Don't buy this game.  Not even if it's on sale.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Disclaimer: I have only played the single-player portion of the game.  Recaptures the feel and subtle complexity of the original Heroes game while adding larger tactical combat maps, additional inventory options, zones of control and swapable buildings in the cities.  The biggest weakness is the game's interface which can seem a bit awkward.  Overall, I'd recommend it, especially on sale.  Beware, however, as the game uses (and requires the installation of) Uplay, Ubisoft's DRM system.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2014
												I'm writting this after playing foor 10hrs straight. I played all of the Heroes games ever made (including the expansions) and I can safely state that this is now absolutely my new favourite one.Some people complain that the game is buggy, but I've yet to encounter anything like that. The game runs great.On the same note, the landscapes are breathtaking and the Art direction for the creatures and characters is truely original (as far as Heroes games go). Heroes skill sytem is complex and rewarding and the storyline is interesting enough to not be dismissed as "generic".I don't know what else to say, if you're a diehard Heroes fan like myself, don't listen to anyone else, give it a chance. I'm really happy I did!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												A good game in a great franchise ruined by a bad company.  You can see that I have a lot of hours logged into this game.  What you don't see is that a tremendous number of those hours are idle; I simply refused to log out because I thoroughly distrusted uPlay to the point of not believing I would ever be able to log back in if I logged out.  Previous experience justified that fear.  Subsequent experience validated it.  I finally had to reboot my machine.  Once again, I cannot get into the game because of uPlay.  The latest "update" to uPlay upgraded my experience by once again denying it to me entirely--as in, where I once could log on, I no longer can.When I was in the game, I was able to get through the first campaign and part of the second.  The game is a respectable member of the HOMM franchise but nothing truly revolutionary (the primary new element, dynasty weapons, is a good concept and I hope that it appears again, but it isn't exactly series-defining), and there are definite power balance issues among the factions.  Fortunately for beginners, you start playing the easiest (most powerful) faction (Necropolis), but the balance issues could be serious in multiplayer with random factions.The bottom line is simple: Not only do I not recommend this game for as long as uPlay exists, but I personally will not buy another Ubisoft title of any kind until they abandon or dramatically reform that system.  There are many excellent publishers out there that treat their customers with more respect, or failing that, if they force you to use proprietary portals, at least they function.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												A horrid disappointment.  I loved the older Heroes of Might and Magic games.  They provided a good mix of RPG and strategy and were fairly well balanced.  This game does not meet the expectations is predecessors provide.  The balance is perhaps the worst offender, being completely tossed out the window.  With the slightest difference in how you play, the experience can be either an utter cake-walk or an impossible death march.  All aspects of the RPG and Strategy sides of the game are severely diminished compared to its predecessors too, resulting in a very shallow, un-fun experience.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												Where to begin?  Wierdly, I feel let down by this game.  That's even taking into consideration I picked this game up in the sale for 7.99 because at this moment that feels like about 7.99 more than I should have paid.Firstly, you need to open the game UPlayer - which doesnt work and will come up saying "uplay uplayer has stopped" everytime unless you run as an admin from outside steam - which then opens the game through Steam requiring both Steam and UPlayer to be open simultaneously to run the game which is a complete FARSE.Secondly, having played previous HoMM titles I wasn't expecting the wheel to be reinvented - in fact I bought the game specifically to quench my thirst for turn based fantasy.  I then go into the game open up the custom game option and find that you can't even so much as change your faction without going through the games dynasty system ( a system basically set up to milk cash out of online play) and nor can you change the faction of AI players at all.  This is in "custom" games.  After realising this I went back to the menu and the more I looked at the game and it's features the more I felt that it didn't look like a game anymore, it looked like a F2P app with in game purchases.  Don't buy this game.  Not even if it's on sale.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												A good game in a great franchise ruined by a bad company.  You can see that I have a lot of hours logged into this game.  What you don't see is that a tremendous number of those hours are idle; I simply refused to log out because I thoroughly distrusted uPlay to the point of not believing I would ever be able to log back in if I logged out.  Previous experience justified that fear.  Subsequent experience validated it.  I finally had to reboot my machine.  Once again, I cannot get into the game because of uPlay.  The latest "update" to uPlay upgraded my experience by once again denying it to me entirely--as in, where I once could log on, I no longer can.When I was in the game, I was able to get through the first campaign and part of the second.  The game is a respectable member of the HOMM franchise but nothing truly revolutionary (the primary new element, dynasty weapons, is a good concept and I hope that it appears again, but it isn't exactly series-defining), and there are definite power balance issues among the factions.  Fortunately for beginners, you start playing the easiest (most powerful) faction (Necropolis), but the balance issues could be serious in multiplayer with random factions.The bottom line is simple: Not only do I not recommend this game for as long as uPlay exists, but I personally will not buy another Ubisoft title of any kind until they abandon or dramatically reform that system.  There are many excellent publishers out there that treat their customers with more respect, or failing that, if they force you to use proprietary portals, at least they function.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												A horrid disappointment.  I loved the older Heroes of Might and Magic games.  They provided a good mix of RPG and strategy and were fairly well balanced.  This game does not meet the expectations is predecessors provide.  The balance is perhaps the worst offender, being completely tossed out the window.  With the slightest difference in how you play, the experience can be either an utter cake-walk or an impossible death march.  All aspects of the RPG and Strategy sides of the game are severely diminished compared to its predecessors too, resulting in a very shallow, un-fun experience.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												A fun, intuitive and challenging game, Heroes VI is my favourite in the series. The graphics are BEAUTIFUL and the real-time battle models look astounding. Battles are a mix of complicated turn-based, chess-like gameplay, with interesting, game-changing abilities. The maps are fun to explore and are filled with treasure and plenty of monsters to fight. One thing worth noting is the difficulty of the campaigns. The AI are smart and aggresive. So if you are are a fan of being  able to say, "I've finished this game, good luck at doing it yourself", then you will really enjoy this. Heroes VI is also great fun to play against friends. It features a hot-seat gametype which can be tedious if you don't like waiting for your slow friend, though the AI in Custom Game will be a worthy, oppenent in an actual player's stead. So, if you are a fan of expansive, challenging strategy games or enjoyed the other games in this series, this should be an memorable experience.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												For starters, if you are like me a genuine HOMM fan. Stay away from this nightmare.I've been playing the HOMM for as long as I can remember.And this game truly is a let down.The story is thin and is lacking any kind of depth that would make the player intrigued to advance further into the campaign.The selection of factions and interesting creatures are slim. Thou they've added a completely new faction. Which is on the upside, but it does not counter the negative aspects of the others.The heroes themself have somekind of RPGish levling, which is to me just confusing.Balance of the game is all roody poo, I can't put my finger on it. And neither can the devs, or so it seems.All creatures has way too many perks and active effects it's all just a big mess.It's like the devs have gone tryhard on this game, making it as complicated and frustrating as possible.Oh, and you need to be online at all time during your session and connected to Ubisoft's Conflux service. If you happen to go offline while playing, all your progress is lost. Neat, right?If you happen to be new to the HOMM series you might actually like this game, since it has some good points as well.I'm not the one to tell them, there's plenty of positive rewievs for that.But as an old HOMM player, I'd suggest you stick with either HOMM 3 or 5.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2015
												Though I've not played anywhere NEAR as much as the time logged indicates, I will say - I have tried to like this game.  But, it's AI basically amounts to building armies at 3-4 times your rate.  Even on easy.  They aren't brilliant (I watched the last orc attacking my city, who was alrwady INSIDE the city, turn and attack the wall leading in).  They're just overtly numerous.  2-3 heroes with armies bigger than your main army can muster (again, even on easy for the Haven campaign) will be constantly on the attack, and in your zone.It's sad, because I've come back TRYING to like this game.  I'm not a Heroes III fanatic, in fact I didn't even play it.  But though I DID like Heroes V, I didn't judge this against it.  I'm merely saying an unfinished game at release was obviously glossed over as 'completed' by simply letting an ignorant AI outnumber you to your death.  I don't recommend.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Personally I find this to be the best HoMM game since the 3rd, don't really get the bad rep it got which seems to be aimed mostly towards uplay rather than the game itself, it's a shame.Unlike HoMM 5 the maps aren't nearly as linear (which was my biggest issue with the 5th entry)Neither have I run into too many bugs other than the camera-bug which makes me unable to look around with my mouse and having to nagivate with the arrow-keys instead (only a reboot seems to fix this from my experience) but fortunately it doesn't occure too often. Unlike the 3rd one you don't have the whole RNG randomness of skills whenever a hero lvls up, instead you get this RPG-esque option to put out talent points into either Magic or Might. The balance doesn't seem to be all there neither, might is a far superior choice over magic from what i've seen and the factions seems to be a bit unbalanced as well. There are less resources to think about, etc. You can also not steal mines in the same way you could previously since they are all connected to the owner of the nearby town so it's a bit less micro-heavy than previously as well. For some this might be a big issue.While the overarching story might not be anything amazing (neither was any of the previous installment's stories) I still enjoyed the campaign a great deal, playing from the different perspectives of Duke Slava's children, one for each faction.And honestly if you are into the story that much I'd recommend going for the Might & Magic series instead.All in all, It's a fun game if you can look past the whole double-DRM thing and some changed core features such as less resources and how the whole territory-war works.

The balance doesn't seem to be all there neither, might is a far superior choice over magic from what i've seen and the factions seems to be a bit unbalanced as well. There are less resources to think about, etc. You can also not steal mines in the same way you could previously since they are all connected to the owner of the nearby town so it's a bit less micro-heavy than previously as well. For some this might be a big issue.While the overarching story might not be anything amazing (neither was any of the previous installment's stories) I still enjoyed the campaign a great deal, playing from the different perspectives of Duke Slava's children, one for each faction.And honestly if you are into the story that much I'd recommend going for the Might & Magic series instead.All in all, It's a fun game if you can look past the whole double-DRM thing and some changed core features such as less resources and how the whole territory-war works.

Posted: October 18, 2014
												Personally I find this to be the best HoMM game since the 3rd, don't really get the bad rep it got which seems to be aimed mostly towards uplay rather than the game itself, it's a shame.Unlike HoMM 5 the maps aren't nearly as linear (which was my biggest issue with the 5th entry)Neither have I run into too many bugs other than the camera-bug which makes me unable to look around with my mouse and having to nagivate with the arrow-keys instead (only a reboot seems to fix this from my experience) but fortunately it doesn't occure too often. Unlike the 3rd one you don't have the whole RNG randomness of skills whenever a hero lvls up, instead you get this RPG-esque option to put out talent points into either Magic or Might. The balance doesn't seem to be all there neither, might is a far superior choice over magic from what i've seen and the factions seems to be a bit unbalanced as well. There are less resources to think about, etc. You can also not steal mines in the same way you could previously since they are all connected to the owner of the nearby town so it's a bit less micro-heavy than previously as well. For some this might be a big issue.While the overarching story might not be anything amazing (neither was any of the previous installment's stories) I still enjoyed the campaign a great deal, playing from the different perspectives of Duke Slava's children, one for each faction.And honestly if you are into the story that much I'd recommend going for the Might & Magic series instead.All in all, It's a fun game if you can look past the whole double-DRM thing and some changed core features such as less resources and how the whole territory-war works.

												Though I've not played anywhere NEAR as much as the time logged indicates, I will say - I have tried to like this game.  But, it's AI basically amounts to building armies at 3-4 times your rate.  Even on easy.  They aren't brilliant (I watched the last orc attacking my city, who was alrwady INSIDE the city, turn and attack the wall leading in).  They're just overtly numerous.  2-3 heroes with armies bigger than your main army can muster (again, even on easy for the Haven campaign) will be constantly on the attack, and in your zone.It's sad, because I've come back TRYING to like this game.  I'm not a Heroes III fanatic, in fact I didn't even play it.  But though I DID like Heroes V, I didn't judge this against it.  I'm merely saying an unfinished game at release was obviously glossed over as 'completed' by simply letting an ignorant AI outnumber you to your death.  I don't recommend.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												My only complaint is that all the maps are pregenerated - you can't generate random maps.The gameplay is a balancing act of economy building which is pretty subtle.  I lost an easy map 3 times before figuring out a way that worked (and even then I might have just gotten lucky).The music is excellent - which means a lot coming from me.  I'm very picky about music.Also the artwork is very well done and nice to come back to.This is not a TBS like Civilization, because the maps are very linear and sort of contrived.  You can't build as many cities as you want - everything is fixed on the maps.  But it's still FUN and really artful and some of the artwork is so good I'll forget about the game for months and then an image pops up in my head and I want to play this again.The tactics are interesting because some units take up more than a single square - like 2x2.  In those cases you can set up shielding formations to protect your most important units, maybe other cases too.Yes buy it.Also... as far as Uplay goes... yes it's a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ but so is Steam.  It's just another platform and this is just the way developers do marketting.  I don't care.  I can still get to the gameplay and I enjoy it once I get there.  That's all I care about.  Uplay IS a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥though - they want to suggest 2-step verification.  Guess what Uplay - this is a ♥♥♥♥ing game not a bank account I don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about your stupide 2-step verification ideas!

Posted: October 1, 2016
												FROM A HoM&M AVID PLAYER: AVOID AT ALL COSTSEvery month there is a problem with connecting to the server: once it's an ubisoft update, another time the maintenance works which always take more time than scheduled, other times it just keeps disconnecting for unknown reasons, today it's a bad uplay update ( uplay has caused a lot of problems so far) etc... the end result is that you can't play this game decently!  I'm still of the ( maybe old fashioned??) idea that if you pay good money for a game you have the right to play when you want and as much as you want. The number of times I couldn't play with this game and the way Ubisoft keeps on failing by giving very little or no customer support only points to one conclusion: DON'T BUY this piece of junk.I've played and enjoyed all the Heroes of Might and Magic and I'm completely disappointed with Ubisoft because it has completely ruined the franchise both by pairing with Uplay and by making the content of the game only available when connected to the game server (conflux). As curious as I was about HoM&M VII I won't buy it. If you want to enjoy this franchise go back, play the V, IV, III and II, but don't buy this and the following one at these absurd conditions, where you can only  play every other week and with Ubisoft replying to your submitted ticket 1 month later, when the old issue is resolved and a new one has just arisen.

												You will probably need this instruction:- I uninstalled Uplay entirely. ***It leaves files behind! Go to your \program files (x86)\ folder and delete the Ubisoft folder there completely. This was necessary for me to do***- I restarted my computer (had to do this too, no restart after removal/installation did nothing for me before)- I re-installed Uplay using the installer found on Uplay's website.- After installation, I restarted again.- I launched the game through Steam and after about a minute, Uplay finally came up without crashing and updated itself.- Exit Uplay.- Re-launch the game through Steam again, and now you can input your key to activate it.Well done, 3 years seems not enough to fix it. Such instructions made me remember good old 90s

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
Probably the Best "Heroes" since HMM III.PreambleBeing a massive fan of HMMIII, and having played all the following games in the series (Except M&M: HVII) I would rather warmly recommend M&M:HVI.While the game was first plagued by game breaking issues courtesy of Ubisoft's dodgy DRM, numerous bugs, and a lack of Town screen which caused an uproar when the game first released, these problems were eventually addressed. I think a lot of the negative reviews date back to the olden days of 2011 In my infinite wisdom, I only bought the game a year or so after it released, and my experience was only slightly mired by the innate DRM and Conflux systems. I've not played all the DLC content available today for M&M:HVI, only Shades of Darkness (SoD), so this is the scope of this review.  The GoodThe campaigns are interesting overall, with some of them really shining as possibly the best campaigns  in the entire series. This is particularly true for the SoD extension which was thoroughly enjoyable in my opinion. I liked as well that the main heroes in campaigns are related to the other heroes by an overarching story frame, which - to boot - allows you to play the campaigns in pretty much any order. The game also includes the "Dynasty system" allowing you to unlock Heroes and additional bonuses that can then be used in multiplayer and other modes, as well as weapons and pets for your campaign Heroes.Last but not least, also included is a Karma system of sorts which, through your choices and actions, allows to you to gear your main Heroes towards super-good or mega-evil, thus gaining equally good or evil superpowers. This is a tiered system, which at first provides small but useful advantages, but by the time you reach the last scenario in a campaign will give your Hero some massive bonuses. This adds another level of customization to your heroes and provides some replay value for the campaigns. The profusion of ways in which your Heroes can be tweaked, upgraded and customized will give the min-maxers a great time. Graphics and audio are pretty good, though some of the voice acting can be a bit off-putting at times, but overall the presentation is pretty good. The gameplay, exploration, city management, kingdom building, hero development are all very enjoyable. The battle system while being very classic is also very enjoyable thanks to a clear interface, nice graphics and animations (which after a few hours you will certainly want to speed up !)The BadOn the downside, you have to bear with an "AI", which at times is so obviously scripted that it becomes a bit of an immersion breaker. (Hello Inferno campaign!). The Truly EvilAh! UBISOFT darling when will you understand that such heavy handed DRM only affects the people who actually purchase your games? We're not in 1990 anymore when everyone was burning "backup" copies of games and "lending" them to our friends! We have the internet and we have smarts! We can download in a few mere minutes DRM-free versions of your games and enjoy their content without your annoying, crippling, absurd and utterly pointless DRM!To the point, Uplay, the DRM, should really be called Udontplay, because frankly it can be pretty hard to get the game to start after installing it. Thankfully in most cases you will find the solution in this here forum or on the web.ConclusionLastly, once you are past the DRM Gates of Hell, Heroes VI, offers great gameplay and a huge amount of content to play through, even more so nowadays with all DLCs available. Overall, with 313 hours on my counter, I must say I have very much enjoyed Heroes VI + SoD, more so than any other since the days of HMMIII. (Excluding Heroes VII- which, in my still infinite wisdom, I will not buy before Ubi gets their game together so to speak.)

												I don't understand all of the negative reviews of this game. It isn't on par with, say, MM3 but it is a very fun and addictive game as well with it's own unique charm. The graphics are great, the gameplay is tweaked but maintains the classic Heroes vibe. All the DLC is a bit of a turn off and the lack of custom map making is a step backwards but overall it is a good addition to the universe.A lot of people complain about Uplay but I have not experienced any of these problems. Perhaps the complaints are outdated? I can play online without issue, Uplay functions perfectly. I have had one instance of a game crash but that was after hours of play and enabling the daily save feature makes it so that the odd crash really isn't much of an issue.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												I just finished the HoMM V after playing it for the first time this weekend.And loved the game so much I bought the Hammers of Fate expansion as well as HoMM VI and also started playing HoMM Online as well.Way back in 2002 I had purchased what I believe was HoMM IV, my first HoMM game and I recall within minutes not liking it, deleting it and for the next 13 years avoiding all HoMM titles.GEEEEEEZZZZZ, what was I thinking!?!On a whim, I played Kings Bounty for the first time last Friday, "KB: Legend"...I loved it !And also was happy to find out that HoMM and KB are related.This got me thinking to give HoMM a 2nd chance, so I bought HoMM V and OMG I love it!I could not stop playing it!Although, I finished it, I still have Hammer of Fate to play.But, that could not stop me from wanting to try HoMM VI with its upgraded graphics.My initial hesitation on Steam to return to HoMM games was due to mixed reviews regarding the versions of HoMM that require the infamous "UPlay".But, being a techie I was determined to not let UPlay ruin my fun.Despite, not being able to play HoMM VI due to a UPlay error, that caused me to RAGE, I was able to get it to run with the help of our Steam forum members.As a result, I LOVE HoMM VI as well!1) Updated graphics2) Beautiful Sound Track3) Plays just like HoMM V, but with some changes that others complained about, but I do not mind.My only complaints thus far is that the voice acting is not as good as HoMM V, the Orc sounds downright cheesey. And of course the cinstant connection, Conflux and UPlay all adding to disk usage and duplicating Steam.if you never played a HoMM game before, let me tell you that the game design is very uniquer and fun and is being imitated by other games.For me, the allure is the way the game switches from strategic view to tactical view where the battles are fought.Loving it

												Very good game.Pros: 1) Nice graphics and beautiful environment 2) Engaging gameplay after a few hours of adaptation 3) Ability to convert cities of other fractions 4) Well made animation of units and spells (exept might hero basic attack) 5) New skill distribution system, which allows you to build your hero the exact way you want him 6) Interesting blood/tears reputation abilities  7) Dynasty weapons and perks 8) Music 9) Overall creature growth and hire - very usefulCons: 1) Cities. Awful cities as before as after the patch 2) Sometimes inappropriate units' voices 3) Somewhat lazy made storyline in main campaingsI recommend this game to every heroes series' fan (exept those who like thirds and thirds only) and to everyone who likes strategies. If you've played thirds' fourths and fifths at least try to give this game a chance. I too was very angry at developers at first for their innovations, but after a few days i understood that this game is good, despite all negative sides (Cities). Looking back now, i regret that i didn't bought this game before, when Blackhole studios (original developers) still existed.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
												The only gripe I people seem to have with this game is its use of Uplay. Frankly, I've never had problems with Uplay, and a second layer of DRM on top of Steam (which is DRM in itself, we must all remember) does not bother me. When it comes to the game itself, I greatly enjoy it; a breath of fresh air into the HoMM series, which since Heroes III, has been based on the same formula which quite frankly has been getting somewhat stale. The amalgamation of all the tedious resources into one, crystals is, in my opinion, a good idea. Whilst it simplifies the game, the introduction of the region system means it would be very tedious to capture all of the resource production buildings, even more so than in HoMM III & V. The graphics, even now, as I write this in 2015, are gorgeous. The creature design in this game is the best it has been in the series. The units are original and the art direction in general is great.Similarly the introduction of deeper RPG elements makes the game more interesting and helps the player invest themselves into the world. What can I say, I like this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Well, I have over 600 hours in the game, so perhaps I should write a review.  For context, I'm a shameless HOMM fanboy; I started back in the day with HOMM II, and recently replayed III, IV, and V, just for the nostalgia (and in preparation for MMH7's release).This game did have some game-breaking bugs in its early days; today, only one remains that I can detect, and that is the "NVidia card causes black town/combat screen" bug.  I actually picked up a Radeon card just to get around that bug - that's how much I enjoy the game.  When the game first came out, it had one bug that I found highly amusing ... if you chose to speed up the combat animations, the sound would also be sped up, to the point where it sounded like a bunch of mice screaming and yelling.  Maybe I'm easily amused ... but the bug still exists in the Dungeon campaign (SoD), which I recently re-played ... and it was still worth a chuckle.Nearly all of my gameplay has been campaign - I enjoy those more than anything else, although I can't easily explain why.  This installment, when you include Shades of Darkness and Pirates, has numerous campaigns, which allow you to fully explore the various factions and reputation paths.  The whole dynasty thing was moderately interesting, but tended to offer too much temptation to lean on "dynasty traits", which could really upset the balance of the heroes.  The dynasty weapons, which attain new abilities as they level up, are the highlight of the dynasty system, in my opinion.I'm not going to nit-pick the pros and cons, as other reviews have already done that in great detail - I'll keep them simple:Pros:Very open skill tree (also see cons)Cutscenes are interesting and relevant (Pirates had some amusing content)A tremendous variety of combinations of factions, artifacts, etc., keep things interestingSpell cooldown during combat, while limiting, is realistic and forces you to use your brain a bitReduced resource granularity helps to keep the focus on playing the game, versus constantly juggling resourcesHaving all creatures in all towns available to hire from any town ... nice!Fixed perspective camera, versus the crazy controls in HOMM VTakes full advantage of 2560x1440 monitorGreat musical scoreCons:The skill tree doesn't let you go as far with certain skills; consider Grandmaster Pathfinding in HOMM IV (no terrain penalty, +50% movement).  In MMH6, every hero can have logistics, but it's limited.Some campaigns tend to be a bit suffocatingWhen morale gives a stack an additional move, it's not a full move; less movement, and less damageThat's really it.  Overall, 9/10 from me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												This game is basically just inferior to HoMM5 in nearly every way. It appears to use the same engine/assets for many things, which by itself is not necessarily a bad thing. This is probably the nicest thing I have to say about it. The story seems to be set in the same world as the previous game, but is completely unrelated. Again, not necessarily a bad thing, if not for the fact that the delivery of said story was far worse than in HoMM5. The voice acting was mediocre, and the writing is on the same level. While I could not force myself to further the story to try the gameplay in later missions, there doesn't appear to be anything new. Not that I expect there to be, since it is still the same engine.The real warehouse of nails in this game's coffin is the fact that it forces you to use uPlay. Why Ubisoft feels the need for more DRM in top of Steam is beyond me, and why they decided to make this DRM as bad as it is is a rabbit hole down which I dare not go. In any case, expect to spend close to an hour trying to figure out why uPlay is crashing, failing to patch, and not linking to Steam (a feature it claims to have). Oh, and this is all assuming the servers are up. When you do get it to work, you will still probably have to work around uPlay "features", like it's overlay, which interfere's with Steam's overlay, and the strange GFWL-style secondary menu that looks like part of the game but isn't.Overall, I would recommend this game to literally no one. If you're new to the franchise, do not start with this game. See if you can find a friend with a copy of HoMM5, preferably on a disk so that you don't have to deal with Ubisoft's DRM. If you're a veteran, you probably own one of the other games already. I would suggest modding them, or just replaying the older ones, until the 7th installment of the series comes out. Not that I have high hopes.In summary, incredibly mediocre rehash of the last game with no improvements, difficult to set up because of uPlay being terrible.3/10At least, if you do get it working, the custom games aren't too much worse than before.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2016
												I'll be straightforward.I don't have a problem with the ubi launcher. It's a fail, but it does the job done. When it works.I don't have a problem with the dumped down resources. Although i prefer the old system, i can live with it.I don't have a problem with difficulty in general. Sometimes it can get rediculous, but you can also change it to easy.Where i do have the problem though, is with the games core mechanic that increases enemies army size every week like the players. It may look nice on paper and you can dump it down a little through difficult settings, but if you take your time (like me) wandering around the beautiful crafted map, or sometimes just killing every army you encounter, you'll hit sooner or later an overpowered enemy wall that you cannot cross.This is by the far the worse thing in the game in my opinion. It forces you to play fast and precise, otherwise you may end up in a really tight situation. Why? Why in earth can't i define my own game pace? It makes no sense. And if they liked that mechanism so much, why don't they just put a slider or something so the players can adjust in a precise way the amount of reinforcements enemies can get? Bad design choice.Apart of this, the game is nice with all it's problems. And it has lots, just read the following reviews. But it's also fun, has gorgeous graphics and a beautiful designed enviroment. Oh and the animations, are one of the best i've seen, kudos to the animation team/studio.It's a good game, full of bad design choices. A  5/10  from a series veteran.A solid  7/10  for the newcomers or the ones who simply don't care.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												I love the M&M series and have been playing it since HOMM 2 (I later went and purchased the bundle pack of HOMM 2 so I could experience HOMM 1). This game brings alot of changes to the series and I personally like the fresh take on the series. Major changes include, the new leveling system, spell system, blood and tears system, and dynasty system.The leveling system is different in this entry in that you actually get to choose the path and perks of your hero as they level. While this gets rid of a bit of the luck side of things when leveling it adds a strategy layer to picking your perks and leveling your hero. For those new to the series, in older games when your hero leveled you got to pick from a selection of randomly generated perks and skills. Sometimes you got the ones you wanted... sometimes you didnt. I can see how some loyal heroes fans would be upset about this major change but I personally enjoyed it. I felt like I had far more control over the outcome of my hero.The spell system in this entry has been overhauled as well. In previous games you would have schools of magic and spells that fell under those schools. You'd build mage guilds in your towns and get a random selection of spells from different schools of magic. Certain Factions were more likely to get specific magic types. In this game schools of magic are only available to certain factions. Spells and perks that you would get from a school of magic are part of the leveling system. When you level up you can pick a spell, a skill, or a perk. You no longer learn spells from mage guilds and shrines. I can understand how this draws away from classic heroes and can upset some devout fans but I believe the outcome is better. You can learn your spells on the fly (without having to go back to town everytime you buy a new level in the mage guild), Certain high level spells are restricted to level requirements (no level 5 guy smashing your team with death ripple), and you can pick between a weaker but wider range of spells or focus in a specific school and make those spells stronger. Again I believe it adds an extra layer of strategy and gets rid of some of the luck.the Blood and Tears System is an entirely new addition to the heroes franchise. The system rewards consistant gameplay style by giving you points towards your style. Blood being ruthless and tears being compasionate. You gain points for actions such as persuing and slaughtering lesser creatures (blood), or allowing them to flee (tears). When you get enough points your hero gains a special perk garnered to that gameplay style. It's an interesting feature and certainly brings something to the table. I found myself many a time slaughtering weak armies just for the blood points when i'd normally let them flee just to save combat time.The Dynasty system is a new addition as well. This particular addition came with some powerful perks at the cost of a miriad of major drawbacks. Perks include weapons with their own leveling system that can be passed from hero to hero and small perks that could give a starting advantage to new games. The DRM system forces you to be online in order to take advantage of the perks you can gain through dynasty. It can be relatively annoying if your playing games and you are disconnected. All in all I enjoyed the game and got my moneys worth out of it. While I understand that the vast majority of the negative reviews are for bugs or the DRM system the game itself is worth playing and is IMO the best HOMM available on steam. That being said HOMM 3 (and its expansions) is probably still my favorite entry in the series and is available on GOG.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
												New to the Series? This game is a good starting point! Worried about the User Review? The game had a horrible launch with connection issues, bugs and so on... but it was years ago.Story and Lore ? I liked it, the graphics + music + voice acting + decent story, can be pretty immersive. Gameplay? Pretty standard, if you a heroes vet you might not like it. Because some simplifying of features has been done, but on the other hand they added some other things, like a progress system, for your account and for special weapons.Why to bother with a review this late? Because overall i enjoyed this game and it makes me sad seeing  49% review rate... its like a heavy scar that the game will always carry on for the mistakes of the past, if i would guess i think this game would have sit on 80% rate at least if it was released at its current state.Something to be aware of although : Dont buy this for the multiplayer, its pretty much dead.And it seems that some people are still experiencing problems, i had zero of those and i think that 99% of the problems can be fixed, just need to understand how, but its definitely something to consider before getting the game. If you never had issues with Ubisoft or fixed any you had then i dont think you will have any with this game either.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												I have spend many hours in the campaign, which is quite good.  However, due to how the AI seems to be given units rather than produce them like you, it feels like like King's Quest.  It's an entertaining adventure, but it does force you to play the heal/ressurect game, otherwise you will not be able to survive many hard battles.  Treat the campaign as an RPG adventure, where your stacks and hero develop with you.  Because the rest of the game is very lackluster.  The skirmishes were extremely boring, especially because you can convert cities to your faction and then recruit from a single pool.  It makes the game very snowbally, where you just throw all your stuff into one spot, and if you win, you gain another city and more of the same units.  You have to use U-play which caused problems for some, though not me.To summerize - Campaign is good, rest is bland.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Turn Based Strategy / Fantasy*Important BugsOverall 3 out of 5Complexity 3Graphics 3Immersive 3Inovative 3Game Pace 2This is a hard call between recommending or not, but at the end I think it is worth the money if you find a good discount.To make it easier I split the review in pro and against.Pro:This is very much like the original games, the ones that got very popular, with the addition of a relevant achievement system.There is this extra layer to the game where you create your heroes and give them the habilities, and as you play you do not only level in game but you also level your profile and acquire in game coins. This profile leveling allows you to expand the set of options for your heroe and the coins to acquire more habilities and other stuff for your set.It's interesting and fun developing your profile as if it as an in game character, and it gives extra game hours.The game itself is pretty much like the series, you have castles, armies, heroes and resources and you are in a row for conquering it all. The AI is decent enough, the creatures have a nice variation of habilities and magic is interesting although narrow.If you like the series, this is a good call. I personally didn't like the Heroes V, but this one I did. There's plenty hours of game in.Against:Ubisoft have been showing a tendency to shady business in recent developments, and this seems pretty much it.The games have loads of bugs that will probably never be fixed, it crashes, hangs, etc. also the Uplay is mandatory for this game, but there are bugs syncronising content making the loading a pain. Almost every time I open the game I have to wait for a long attempt to syncronise content with their server, eventually it fails for time out, and only then I can play.Another hint that Ubisoft do not really care much for fair play is that this is not a full version. You'll not find the Dungeon available, the only way to get this is to buy another fully independent game by a price way above a game pack. I'm also not sure if this is the only thing missing as I originally bought two game packs along with this because of a sale.Bugs and shady business aside there's one more annoyance, if you are a fan of multiplayer or stand alone, to take the most of the game you'll have to at least play one campaing with your favourite race, aside the introductory campaing. This is the only way to unlock some special items that will be attached to your account.The introdutoring campain is boring like hell but is "short", the race campain I can only tell about the Undead which is not bad.All in all, there's no other game like this. Falling Enchantress gets close to beat Heroes, but it misses some fundamental stuff. Others are too simple to be interesting for long... so in my opinion this is worth for the simple reason that there's no competitors for this game style, specially if you want to play with friends.If you are looking at games at random and not after this game style in specific, then stay away.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												DRM and Uplay are the two biggest problems with this game. ~If ubisofts servers go down, it will literally boot you to the main menu in the middle of your game, and not let you continue with what you were doing.  What the actual ♥♥♥♥.~You must download and install Uplay to play this, which is a garbage cloud. When you launch from steam, it will launch the Uplay cloud first and then launch heroes. If uplay is down, you cannot launch heroes. ~Nvida card users probably will experience black screen of death often. There are multiple sollutions and checklists its fixable you just got to do it yourself.Cons about the actual gameplay.~In campaign, easy mode is to easy, normal mode is too challenging. There is no middle ground.~Against AI in custom games, hard mode is too easy oddly enough even without dynasty bonus's.~Combat can become stale.Cons about the story.~Not the most memorable story.~Can feel a bit detached from the fantasy world, not news for a heroes game tho. Every character without a name is just generic and it feels like there are only a handful of characters in this universe. ________________________________________________________________________________Rather then give you a list of pros with this recommend, I will just give you what I feel are the cons. Heroes 6 does deliver and will provide many hours of gameplay if you can look past the cons.

content:
Posted: September 7, 2012
												Might & Magic Heroes VI has the potential to be a superb game, but is held back by one minor and one monumental flaw.The graphics as expected are superior to previous titles in the series. The music and faction/unit versatility is on par at best, though being able to split your upgrades in the previous iteration makes unit upgrades in VI seem like a step backwards. Spells and gear are fairly versatile, though once more there is the issue of an optimal" gear set and spells which effectively make 3/4 of your arsenal obsolete.One of the  two places where the game falls short for me is the story and character script, which whilst brilliant for most games, just isn't as captivating and moving as previous iterations of Heroes. The second issue, which happens to be the largest deterrent, is the sheer amount of bugs, glitches, freezing and crashes which makes playing the game incredibly frustrating. Seriously Ubisoft... get your♥♥♥♥♥♥together and fix this!

Posted: December 29, 2014
												I love HOMM2, 3, 4, 5 was so so and 6 is awful.  UPlay is a terrible idea and it doesn't work well.  this game looks nice, but they removed the town pictures at first, then we cried and we got it in a patch.  the storyline was mediocre.  sadly, this game just isn't fun to play.  the computer can become severly overpowered ruining single player experience.  having Uplay go down while you are playing means you get boooted from the campaign and then can't continue your 'online' campaign.  happened too many time so I turned it off.  I honestly played this game for nearly 2 hours but was booted from Uplay so many times that I uninstalled it and said never again.    hopefully if there is a HOMM7, they will learn from the terrible mistakes of this game.   as a long time fan, of the series  I was pretty dissapointed.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												1) This game is by Ubisoft 2) It requires Uplay (third party gaming app) to play.     If you are still not convinced not to buy it...3) The launcher now crashes on startup (and is generally buggy), after I took a long time away from playing it.    Why did I stop playing it? Because...4) The game mechanic where you have to mindlessly click through turns just to get a big enough army to defeat the final castle in missions is still very much applicable. Click, click, click...5) Did I mention you can't access your saved games if you are offline, for whatever reason? You actually have to make offline saved games, which are separate from the normal saved games.I played through all campaigns of M&M 5, and all add-ons (a final battle in one of those was bugged, where you just kept fighting the battle over and over). So I've played a fair share. It's a pity about the problems with this one.6) Oh, and with reference to M&M 5. You remember those lovely cities with inspiring music, that were arguably the most enjoyable/well-done features in the game? Well, no longer. They've actually been downgraded.Despite all this, I would actually like to play the game some more. Sadly, point 3 rears it's ugly head.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												This game is basically just inferior to HoMM5 in nearly every way. It appears to use the same engine/assets for many things, which by itself is not necessarily a bad thing. This is probably the nicest thing I have to say about it. The story seems to be set in the same world as the previous game, but is completely unrelated. Again, not necessarily a bad thing, if not for the fact that the delivery of said story was far worse than in HoMM5. The voice acting was mediocre, and the writing is on the same level. While I could not force myself to further the story to try the gameplay in later missions, there doesn't appear to be anything new. Not that I expect there to be, since it is still the same engine.The real warehouse of nails in this game's coffin is the fact that it forces you to use uPlay. Why Ubisoft feels the need for more DRM in top of Steam is beyond me, and why they decided to make this DRM as bad as it is is a rabbit hole down which I dare not go. In any case, expect to spend close to an hour trying to figure out why uPlay is crashing, failing to patch, and not linking to Steam (a feature it claims to have). Oh, and this is all assuming the servers are up. When you do get it to work, you will still probably have to work around uPlay "features", like it's overlay, which interfere's with Steam's overlay, and the strange GFWL-style secondary menu that looks like part of the game but isn't.Overall, I would recommend this game to literally no one. If you're new to the franchise, do not start with this game. See if you can find a friend with a copy of HoMM5, preferably on a disk so that you don't have to deal with Ubisoft's DRM. If you're a veteran, you probably own one of the other games already. I would suggest modding them, or just replaying the older ones, until the 7th installment of the series comes out. Not that I have high hopes.In summary, incredibly mediocre rehash of the last game with no improvements, difficult to set up because of uPlay being terrible.3/10At least, if you do get it working, the custom games aren't too much worse than before.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2011
												I'm a little disappointed in Ubisoft for taking the Heroes series in kind of a weird direction. If you enjoyed the prior "Heroes" games for things like the cityscapes, faction details, and down-to-earth plots, you won't find all that much of those things in "Heroes VI". What you will find is over-the-top unit designs and a lot of the current trend to make the bad guys seem not so bad after all. The Inferno Faction has really suffered in that regard - it's not so much evil and demons as it is a bunch of misunderstood guys with horns.Gameplay, though - that's what's remained true to all the previous "Heroes" games, and the developers did a lot to expand on the options available to a Hero in terms of the skills and powers they can develop. The AI is a bit smarter, and the game can be very challenging if you don't stay on the ball in the early parts of missions. Some units are a lot more useful than others, and the factions have been homogenized a little bit, and there are only five...

If you want to get from one point to another there are only a few corridors you can take.* Uplay.So to summaries I would not recommend you to buy this game for full price. IF it is one 75% sale then yes it is worth the money. But otherwise I would recommend the third game in the series.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												Really fun game plagued by issues which I believe are mainly related to having to use UPlay. I can't recommend it based on the issues preventing me from even playing. For example, it took me awhile to figure out how to successfully launch the game after installing UPlay. I need to launch the game from Steam without UPlay running or I'll just get a message saying the game is already running. Also, every time I click on a town, the screen darkens and seemingly soft locks. From reading other forum posts, these issues have been occurring for years now so I don't see them ever being addressed.Simply put, I'd avoid spending the money on it. Which sucks because the game itself is really cool. Good job game devs, bad job UPlay devs.

You will lowe it.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2016
												While I appreciate the ideas of trying to change up the game play, all the changes fundimentally make the game worse.The castle mechanic is the biggest detriment. In previous games, having to scout the area to pinpoint a castle was a critical move. In 6, there are boarders which are a big screaming flag that says "Hey! The Castle is right over here!". So then you just run in and grab it.Resource management was also a drawback. In 3-5, Having to make the call to explore, fight for a particular mine, or spend way too much money at the market was run. In 6 you just get crystal and call it good.Ok I lied, the biggest detriment is Ubisoft. You have to log in through their bs system and create all these bs accounts. I just want to click play and run the game. Do not buy this game. If you want true Heroes, buy 3. If you want good Heroes with better graphcis, buy 5 (which was pretty solid).

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Heroes of Might and Magic 6 is an awesome refinement of a tried and true formula. The factions are balanced, the combat is engaging and adds hero abilities into the mix which gives the player the opportunity to build their character in some interesting ways. The campaign is solid, and of course the sandbox mode is always great. HOMM6 is beautiful and is the complete package when it comes to turn based strategy games. The series has been through a ton of revisions and I think they have finally hit something amazing. I'm talking HOMM3 amazing here...
