number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												The best Heroes yet!  I think the designers have finally removed most if not all the issues with the Heroes of Might and Magic series.  (I have been playing since 1 back in the day).  I have enjoyed this one the most so far.  Let me list the issues with the last games and how they have been fixed in 6...1) Crossing your fingers whenever you hero goes up a level, hoping you get the skill you are looking for.  In 6 you may select any skill that you want.  Of course some of them require other lower level skills  and some have hero level limits.2) I have 3 town and they are so far apart, it is going to take me a week just to combine my armies.  In 6 the number of creatures you can buy per week is shared with all towns so as long as your town can build a certain unit you can recruit all of them.  (Works with special building that give you bonus units as well).3) Gosh the enemy took all my mines again and if I retake them I cannot get back to defend my town. (Not enough movement).  In 6, you can take a mine for the turn if you leave your hero on it, but as soon as you leave control returns to the player who has the closest town.  4) Issue I have with 5 - Gee that phoenix has taken 3 moved before my Earth Elemental ever got a 1.  How unfair.  I lose no questions. (Unless I am the phoenix, in this case I hope you enjoy cheese).  In 6 they do have the initiative bar but each unit only gets 1 move a turn.  Much better, so yeah all my units might take an action before yours but only 1 action.5) Wow that is the 3rd chain lightning in a row, magic is so much stronger than might...  In 6 each spell has a cool down time, so no more chain lightning each turn until my 3000 units are toast. Most spells are every 3 turns.6) Alright I am going to build a magic tower, cross fingers...  Oh crap I already have all those spells...  In 6 spells are hero abilities so you can pick whatever you want, no randomness.7) (Not a issues but a cool new thing in 6) - Units have a might and magic attack and defense.  Not just 1 value for attack and 1 for defense.  So you can have the magic user who gets destroyed by the sword but spells / magic attacks do very little to him.My only complaint so far has been the difficult, not that it is too hard but it is out of balance.  90% of the fights I can just hit auto combat and go have a cup of tea.  But the "boss" battle at the end of the map usually requires my hitting next turn for a  few weeks to get enough units to win. (This is after I exploed the whole map.  Perhaps it is my style of play.  I am an explorer not a rusher).

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Plays just like it's forerunners but everything's been given a makeover. A graphical overhaul for one. The magic's been given a lot of attention and is all the better for it and it's got the usual depth for a Might and Magic Heroes game. I've played some of it's recent competitors like the King's Bounty games, Eaodor, the latest Disciples games, etc, but I have to say this played the best and was the best looking of the lot too.Downsides; extra DRM. Not content with just using Steam, you also have to create an account and password for Uplay which Ubisoft's now using with ALL their games now. So you've got one lot of DRM on top of another DRM! Talk about giving the legitimate buyers a hard time! The pirates won't have to put up with all this everytime they want to play the game.If you can overlook that, I would say Might and Magic: Heroes VI is the best of the genre at the moment.

												One of the worst games I have ever played, when I bought this game it was broken for Navidea cards.  They say that has since been fixed (if you beleve them) but it shouldn't have been broken in the first place.  I had the game crash over 10 times, during one of the missions.In addition to flat out crashing this game has other multiple problems 1.each map takes about 6 hours to compleate, not because of gameplay but because of teadiasness.2. each and every unit is required to move at a grouling pace you will litteraly spend hours watching them move.3. because natural units gain more unites over time you can actually have a situation in which it becomes impossible to beat normal unites because your blatently outnumbered. (its so unfair)4. zero depth, I really do mean 0 at least on the main map, moveing around is fun but the building componit so sooooo bad.5. IMPOSSIBLE DIFFUCUTY. I'm actually quite serious about this, I could not get past the second level after the tutioral and I was playing on normal.6. Did I mention that the game is broken.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I suppose this game has split the HOMM community in pieces. Some people hate it, some love it. Im with the latter. Really, i have NO complaints about it (as far as Heroes games go). It improves on nearly every aspect that made the previous games more frustrating F.E. not u can buy all units colectively from all cities, no need to circle through them all to get your units. Another would be that your opponents cant Ninja-cap your mines without taking over the rulling local fort. I could go on on and, but over all, it's a fantastic title for anyone enjoying a challange or strategy games in general. 9/10

content:
Posted: July 29, 2016
												This is probably the best Heroes of Might and Magic game. While Heroes II had better campaigns in it, the Heroes VI campaigns remain good. The AI is excellent - a serious challenge to beat in some battles. Heroes VI also removes one of the most tedious things about HOMM (and i say that as someone who loves these games), which is having to do a running tour of all your cities to keep your armies equalling or outnumbering the AI's.In Heroes VI you can recruit troops with a hero in any town, from any town, speeding things up massively.The option to build advanced town portals that let you teleport between towns you control speed things up again. And since the AI can build the same portals it doesn't make the game any easier.Heroes of different factions also get completely different skill trees from one another, which adds to the variety of the game a lot.The graphics are nice, so is the music. The one downside to Heroes VI compared to earlier games in the series is that to get the best starting bonuses you can get you have to play it online via uplay, which, when you're playing single player, is just a bit of a pain that slows starting a new game or loading a saved one down a bit.This is a minor annoyance though in what is basically a really great game.Some HOMM fans deride Heroes VI for having made some changes to previous games. The mess of Heroes VII resulting from trying to go backwards instead of forwards shows how mistaken those people are imo.The one thing that Heroes VI hasn't changed is that it's still in big part a matter of who can recruit more troops faster - but that's a flaw in the basic type of game it is, not this version of it.

												I'm a fan of Heroes of Might and Magic, and as much as I wanted to enjoy this game, I didn't. The base gameplay is nice enough, but lacks that spark of charm that the classic HoMM titles have, mostly becuase of the change from randomized skills to a linear run-of-the-mill upgrade tree.I could have lived with that, but unfortunately this game has lots of issues. Firstly the difficulty is insane even on easy, due to inbalanced A.I. It's the classic example of having bad A.I. programming, only to try to make it up by making it hugely owerpowered, meaning that you will be attacked by enemies with way too many troops for you to handle.The issues with Uplay are there as well, maning long load times if you're connected to the internet, and lost feautures if you're not. To make it worse saves made with Uplay turned off aren't compatable when playing online, and vice versa. Stick to the older HoMM titles, don't waste your time with this.

 One of the best Turn base strategy games in a world. Game play. Heroes 6 keeps in Heroes 3 traditions gameplay, but stil with changes that makes game even better. Interface is now more comfortable than ever before.  Resources now have only gold, wood, ore and crystals as special resource for advanced buildings and creatures. You can make your costume  Hotkeys which is nice. I have to admit game suffers from balance issues which is a disappointment. Game performence and GraphicIf honest game cold look better. Of course its matter of taste, but still with this graphic game perform quite terribly. Game seams lack of optimization. With my hardware this game should fly. Even such games like Far Cry 3 or Tomb Raider runs stable on 60fps. Probably game should be in 2D graphic than it would look better and would not perform as it does right now. Do not get me wrong. Game still playable but suffers some serious frame drops. I thot that is driver problem, but no I have all drivers up to date.StoryI never was fan of Heroes games story line, but in this game story is really engaging and enjoying. And Heroes profile leveling gives a game adicional value. They call it a Dynasty.ConclusionGame is good, but there need some work to done in order get some genius turn based game which was Heroes 3 at the time. Strategy fans don't need fancy graphic. They need good interface and good idea for game it self. This game is worth your time. You should be patient to play this game. This game takes a lot of time. If you still happy about game after long sessions this means game is good.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 30, 2014
												I would recommend this game overall but this is not one of the best games out there. This game exhibits great RPG elements, and mastering an expertise in battle requires dynamic strategies. However, there are many issues that I have with the game as well. For example the AI is stupid; there are two settings: aggressive and defensive. If you play against defensive then the AI only stockpiles units, which means you will eventually win by sheer force from taking over the map. If you play against aggressive then enemy heroes will only engage in battles that they win in, but only return back to base if forced to. This means that (1) you won't enter in any battles unless your slated to lose (which sometimes means that no matter how resourceful and strategic you are, you will lose); and (2) if you reinforce your main hero then you will eventually overpower the enemy. However, this tends to just end up the AI playing chicken to take your city and you just sitting there until you abuse bad AI scripting to, for example, make them miscalculate. While this makes players think, this doe not make for interesting or fun gameplay. The campaign offers relief from this type of AI stupidity but only sometimes; however, the campaigns did contain some maps that were definitely a puzzle. To be honest, the only reason I recommend this game is because the combat system is engaging, and by abusing the computer's stupidity of amassing units; can reach battles of epic proportions. The hero powers become essential in achieving victory and is the best way this game hands control into the player's hands: all units are balanced among the different races, but it really is how you build your hero that defines a win from a loss. If I could make an ideal 4x game, Heroes of Might & Magic IV would be the type of combat that my game would emulate. That's how fun and different it is from say CIV or SC. However, there are many better strategy games that offer more meaningful experiences where the player has much more choice, not just in hero customization but in building a kingdom. I bought this game thinking it was a strategy game: let me be clear; if that's why you would buy it then do not. This game is an RPG game with strategy elements. Find loot, defend your bases and points of interest; and win by sheer force. If you want a game where you get to control massive and visually epic battles then I'd recommend this game for you.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												I mean... It's HoMM.  Features some interesting improvements over previous incarnations in the series, such as Dynasty Weapons and benefits of controlled territory around cities, and the skilling system is interesting.Suffers a bit from poor optimization, like many other Ubisoft titles, and has a tendency to run sluggishy or choppily, regardless of graphics settings.Is also victim to the recent cancerous gaming growth of "required online connectivity to play," even when playing the single player campaign.  If at any time while playing, you lose connection to the internet (or more importantly, if Uplay goes down, which it frequently does,) your game will immediately exit without saving and you'll be punted back to the main menu.  It's a pretty heartbreaking way to lose a ton of progress.Still, if you're aching for a HoMM game, this is one.  So, that's probably enough for some folks.  Suppose it's recommended, though only by virtue of being a sequel in a series that was once near and dear to my heart.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												Let me set one thing straight before I go off. custom games with your friends is very fun and definitely an enjoyable experience. If this is your sole purpose for buy this game I recommend this game highly.If you are playing for the campaign I recommend that you pass. I've been playing HoMM since Heroes II and I've never experienced such broken gameplay in the campaign. I'll start off with a brief overview of basic gameplay. Each faction has their own special spell that must be built up to by performing specific feats on the battlefield as simple as kill units etc. Special spells include: the Necromancer's have raise the dead, Inferno has gating which allows you summon allies into battle, Sanctuary has a team buff, Haven has a single target shield that gives the unit invulnerability and makes them untragetable and Stronghold gives initiation boost to allies which allows them to move sooner if the boost is enough, although most of the time it isn't. The goal is to build up your town allowing you to recruit more powerful allies as well as provide unique bonues for each faction and eventually defeat your enemies in a "chess-like" battle. During these battles you may use spells that are unlocked Now I will explain why I believe the campaign to be broken. For most if not all of the campaigns you begin without a city, which is fine and completely normal for a Heroes game. Once you have your city you are limited to a certain amount of buildings and the other remain locked until you complete certain tasks or when the game deems it worthy. The AI that you fight in the campaigns is given access to all building at the beginning which means when all you have access to is Tier 1 unupgraded ghouls and skeletal spearmen the enemy is sending out hordes of Tier 2 upgraded Griffons. This is a pain but it is still manageable. Throughout heroes games when you take a city you get all of their upgrades and buildings available for your own use. In the campaign this time around it immediately removes all of their upraded buildings and sets you with your limited structures. So after you fight all these upgraded creatures you dont even have the access to it as the AI did.During battles with the AI is where things really get broken. Every spell you use has a mana cost as well as turn cooldown, such as "you cannot cast this spell again for three turns." The AI for some reason has no limit of mana and may cast the same spell turn after turn not suffering from the cooldown penalty. It takes roughly 2 turns to build up enough of your special spell in order for it to have any use on the battlefield allowing you to cast once every other two turns. The AI seem to build these up in rapid succession allowing them to cast once per turn, and in some rediculous situations i've seen the Haven enemies cast their invulnerability spell twice in one turn. Which means your guys arent hitting anyone but the enemy is, which eventually dwindles down your army. If you are lucky enough to win you will most likely lose 2/3 of your army just to have another enemy attack you in two turns not allowing for you to even begin rebuilding your armyIt seems the devs focused so much on dumbing the game that they forgot to give the enemies a decent AI, because really most of the time its stupid easy even when outnumbered as teh AI makes some really stupid decisions. Which is why they gave them unlimited mana and no cooldowns, that way the game can still remain challenging. Except this isn't the fun kind of challenging. Imagine fighting in PvP and the enemy has hacked the game allowing them to use these same broken mechanics, nothing about that would be fun. The fun challenging is when the AI is using intelligent tactics while you sit there trying to plan one step ahead.6/10+fun battles with friends+each faction is unique (although not as much as previous games)+very cool creatures with their own unique mechanics+enough skirmish maps to try and keep things fresh in custom games+Artifacts are extremely useful+Campaign has a decently interesting story-Bad Voice acting( not really a big deal to me but it is for some so i'll post it up here)-AI is broken in campaign (in custom games it functions properly)-Building the towns has been dumbed down from previous games (Less unique between factions then previous Heroes)-Spell system sucks (Gives us back the Magic Guild buildings please)-Only 3 necessary resources now and you cannot capture an enemies resource-Game almost seems like it was meant for mobile devices with how much everything has been streamlined

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Might & Magic: Heros VI is a RPG-Strategy game.  It has beautiful graphics and music.  The concept of the game looked so interesting and that is why I was initially drawn to it.  The basis of the game is moving your Hero around to collect resources, building up your army and then traveling to fight the final boss.  However, after playing for some hours, trying to complete the campaign.. it lost its appeal.  I find the AI to be extremely overpowered and as I read the other reviews I see I am not the only one.  It requires you to rush through the game to get to the final boss before their armies can become strong.  It doesn't allow you to be able to take your time an explore the area because each turn the opposing army gets stronger.  The Multiplayer is very buggy with lots of dropped connections and sync problems.  This game also (unannounced by steam on the store page) requires Uplay to play.  Uplay is also incredibly buggy and it takes quite awhile just to even be able to play the game.  Overall this game is not good and I would not recommend it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												A surprisingly decent addition to the HoMM series, streamlining Heroes V's developments (only one special resource, no second upgrade option for creatures) while expanding it others (a more comprehensive skill system and the addition of blood and tear abilities) yet a little skimpy on variety in Factions and monster design.  However, it still keeps all the great tactical depth and fun that makes HoMM worthwhile.  I did, on the other hand, not enjoy the feeling that I needed to play the campaign to unlock the full experience, as HoMM's campaigns are not the reason we play them.  I am yet to fully try all the Factions and immerse myself in great non-campaign games, but I was pleased that the core essence of what makes these games great still beats at the heart of this latest episode.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2013
												An extremely fun and well-crafted combination of RPG and turn-based strategy. Adventure and level up with your Heroes - earning skills, spells, and items along the way... but also engage in complex combat sequences of turn-based strategy - involving armies of various units (with various characteristics and abilities) on an isometric grid, similar to a large chess board.Imagine Warcraft (the original RTS games) but everything is turn-based and combat occurs on the "chess-board" screens. You have bases (cities and forts), you collect resources with mines, lumber mills, etc, and you buy new units as time goes on.Warning: the game is a bit buggy, including a few game-breaking bugs that are best avoided if possible (check forums if you are concerned. But Ubisoft is continuously patching these bugs... or so they say, anyway.Still, very fun game, I've already put 200+ hours into it in a couple weeks, and I've barely scratched the surface of the various single player campaigns and mutiplayer options. I recommend it to any RPG and/or strategy fans.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												I love Heroes, was hooked on III especially. This game is pretty alright. People complain about changes to resources and all that, but it's not really a big deal.The problem with this game is that it gets repetitive, fast. Healing your troops up and skipping turns so that you don't lose units. But if you lose units, you get screwed fighting the AI. So your tactics are just stalling trying to save as many units as possible.2nd problem - Bugs. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ bugs. This game should've been delayed for another year+ to fix all the bugs, but they released it, got people's money, and called it a day. Played the beta, said it was buggy, but a decent game. Bought the game on release, bugs were still around. They promise to patch. They patched, there's still enough bugs for at least 3 big patches. And that's what ruined this game for me. You can never be sure your skills, items, heroes do what they say. Stat changes that were obviously suppose to benefit you reverse and screws you over. If this game had its bugs hammered out before release, then yea. Go for it. But at this point, nah. Especially since the expansion brings in more bugs that won't get fixed. Such a shame really.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												I usually don't write reviews. I usually don't feel very strongly about the games I play. They are games, I enjoy them to a certain degree, but that is about the extent of my emotional investment. Now that we have this personal tidbit out of the way, let me begin by saying that I honestly like the Heroes franchise, which includes even the current atrocity and the (for many fans, anyway) mediocre installment that went before it.That is, I would really like to enjoy this game, but for the life of me I can't. Not that it doesn't have some strong suits: The unit models are downright gorgeous, and watching them duke it out in a Heroes-style arena is quite enjoyable. I don't even mind the weak storyline, the presentation of which makes you want to pop some ecstacy (figuratively speaking, of course) just to stay awake. I don't even mind, and I honestly didn't expect much to begin with.What I do mind is the absolutely distasteful, punch-in-the-face, DRM-nightmare platform that Ubisoft ever so tactfully forces upon the player, who put down hard cash to begin with and is most likely eager to play. But wait (and, trust me, you will have to wait a lot if you play this game, but more on that later), first create an account with the fun-loving, family-good-time platform that is Uplay. Already, that dreadful feeling of regret is kreeping along my spine as I feast my eyes, for the very first time, on Uplay and what will from now on be my personal window into the game. I blink once, I blink twice, I try my hardest to ignore the plethora of pile upon pile of achievement, cosmetic-personalization, and fictional-monies/credit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I look only for two things: Activate offline mode and play.The game loads, finally, the main menu appears. Naturally, the game is played. Strangely, some options in the character window are greyed out. The cold sweats are creeping back in. Immediately, I shut down and look for articles that explain this so-called in-game dynasty (not that it requires rocket science).Within minutes, it becomes painfully obvious that, should you choose or want to play the game offline, you're basically looking at a crippled product. Only if you connect to your account are you allowed to choose boni, with which your alter ego begins their adventure, dynasty weapons, pets, and custom heroes (otherwise, the one provided has to do). And, while it is true that these are mere boni, which add to, but are not strictly required in order to finish the game, you're always reminded how you may miss out whenever you find a new dynasty weapon or similar. (It is here I believe Ubisoft's lack of publishing talent is wasted on the gaming industry. They might want to consider psychological warfare.) Best of all, however,  if you wish to reset your progress, you're♥♥♥♥♥♥out of luck: What you do online, stays, at least until Ubisoft goes out of business. Above, I mentioned that your patience will be tested by this game, and it is true. Virtually every minute, you will be greeted by a loading screen. You start the game -- loading screen, you load a save -- loading screen (so far, so normal). The loading screen will stare at you for what will soon become an eternity. You are prompted to press any key to continue. You are now in the game world, but, lo and behold, certain items are missing -- such as your character, or other characters, or flags, or anything animated, really, because these are loaded on the fly after the loading screen (sick of the word "load", yet?) You enter your town, haven, or whatever you want to call it, and the screen says "Loading ..." for a bit. You enter battle, and the screen goes black (loading the battle scene, I presume), and sometimes the scene doesn't load at all. This happens before about 5 % to 10 % of all battles, thusly crashing the game. I cannot quite remember if Uplay attempts to synchronize your saves (a "feature", which can be turned off, fortunately), but when it does, know that you will stare at your screen for 2 to 5 minutes during synchronization.All this being said, I almost pity the developer for having to work under the yoke of Ubisoft and did not (it seems to me) have the opportunity to realize the full potential of the game -- even after the many patches.At any rate, Heroes VI will definitely be the last game I bought that has the Ubisoft sticker on it.

 One of the best Turn base strategy games in a world. Game play. Heroes 6 keeps in Heroes 3 traditions gameplay, but stil with changes that makes game even better. Interface is now more comfortable than ever before.  Resources now have only gold, wood, ore and crystals as special resource for advanced buildings and creatures. You can make your costume  Hotkeys which is nice. I have to admit game suffers from balance issues which is a disappointment. Game performence and GraphicIf honest game cold look better. Of course its matter of taste, but still with this graphic game perform quite terribly. Game seams lack of optimization. With my hardware this game should fly. Even such games like Far Cry 3 or Tomb Raider runs stable on 60fps. Probably game should be in 2D graphic than it would look better and would not perform as it does right now. Do not get me wrong. Game still playable but suffers some serious frame drops. I thot that is driver problem, but no I have all drivers up to date.StoryI never was fan of Heroes games story line, but in this game story is really engaging and enjoying. And Heroes profile leveling gives a game adicional value. They call it a Dynasty.ConclusionGame is good, but there need some work to done in order get some genius turn based game which was Heroes 3 at the time. Strategy fans don't need fancy graphic. They need good interface and good idea for game it self. This game is worth your time. You should be patient to play this game. This game takes a lot of time. If you still happy about game after long sessions this means game is good.

content:

												Hi,first of all, I'm playing HOMM since HOMM3 and together with HOMM6 it is the best part of the series still. I like to think that I'm an experienced player, so the campains aren't too hard yet allthough the necromancer campaign maybe is a little too much for newer players, because the first mission can be quite trying until you know the layout of the map and know what to do early and the second mission you literally aren't allowed to waste a single unit until you reach a nice army size. All in all it offers a nice gaming experience in single player as well as multiplayer mode, if you like round based strategy games.Now the cons; The dynasty weapons don't work in offline mode. I also can't play any singleplayer games that I started offline in online mode and vice versa. I don't know what UBISOFT was thinking when they decided to implement this "idea". As far as I remember they promised this game to be DRM free and technically it is, but instead they force you to be online the whole time and if you lose your connection you can't even continue the single player games you started in online mode.I got this game as a present, otherwise I would've never bought it due to these limitations (allthough I'm a long time HOMM fan). In my opinion Ubisoft is screwing its customers when they promise a non drm game, but make it even worse for paying customers. So my recommendation is a pass, maybe they'll learn to take players more seriously then.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Eh. I bought this for the nostalgia factor for Heroes of Might & Magic. Truth is, the game has promise, but the problem is it just keeps crashing, and it requires you to be always online. Sure, cloud computing is wonderful, but pushing it on you as a default strips a bit of the experience on the user-end of things. And the bugs... ooooh the bugs. The mouse floats and skips about, and some gamers are complaining about it dropping the framerate or killing it entirely. If you try scrolling the screen too quickly after an event (battle, cutscene, dialogue, whatever), it'll break and you can only get the screen to scroll by restarting the game. And if you retreat from a battle with an enemy hero, the game freezes! The game takes forever to switch off due to the uPlay interface synching your game with the cloud, so restarting it becomes a pain. I swear, I get about twenty minutes of good game time before something goes wrong and I have to start over, and waiting between three and five minutes for the game to reboot, and a further couple of minutes to get back to where I was before it froze... it's just not worth it.

This is software like Steam but from a different publisher. So if I start Steam, first Uplay starts and then the game tries to load. If I start Uplay, then Steam starts and afterwards it tries to start Heroes 6. But both time it will not work, I only got to see the game once. With 13h play time its obvious I got the game to work. 												This game is absolutely great, especially if you've been a fan of HoMM in the past.  Leveling up is a bit more predictable, and you get to decide on just about everything instead of it being luck-based as it has in the past, which I prefer.  There are a few bugs with some of the campaign maps, but for the most part there's few issues.  Also, keeping 10 autosaves helps to save you if you screw up or if the game crashes.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
												It had a decent start but it quickly became apparent early on that you couldn't take your time on levels on any difficulty setting as enemy armies grow exceedingly quickly. As a result the only real way to win is to rush through levels as quickly as you can, the exceptions appearing to be the tutorial levels. As someone who prefers to take their time and poke around the inability to do this on even the lowest difficulty is dissapointing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Once you get past the Uplay garbage (turn off cloud saves on Uplay!) it's fun to play.  The story arc is engaging and will keep you coming back for more.  The basic gameplay seems more confined and linear than previous Heroe's of Might and Magic games.  You play one of five children with each it's own faction.  The factions are distinct and you need to play one faction to get to the next one in campaign mode.  It's worth the time and better than your average turn based strategy game.  Worth the price when it go's on sale.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												This isn't a bad game. I've played and loved all of the Heroes games starting from the first one and I think this version has its merits. It looks really good and plays fairly well. They scrapped some of the things I loved from Heroes V including the cool skill progression/mixing and variable unit upgrades which is a bummer. Also they cut the amount of City's you could play as and sold one as DLC. Yes the DLC and Uplay and connectivity stuff are garbage, but that doesn't make the core game not fun. Overall, I would say that if you want to play a game in this series, then buy and play Heroes III Complete and Heroes V w/ expansions. They are cheaper and better than Heroes VI. If you've played those and are looking for a pretty modern take on the series I'd pick up this game. Hopefully they can learn from their mistakes in this one and make the next one a game I can recommend wholeheartedly.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												The game itself is pretty good.It consists of economy management and tactical turn-based combat, using either of five factions who are fun to play but not always very well balanced against each other. You are in control of one or more heroes, who level up after winning enough combats with your army, learning new skills and what-not to use in the following combats. You construct buildings in your towns to recruit soldiers or give other benefits, and you'll soon find out that you're always in the lacks of blood crystals, inciting your continuous exploration. A collecting of sometimes murderously challenging campaigns (at least one for each faction) makes you fine-tune your strategy. This is all pretty damn fun.The factions:Haven - the boring faction consisting of boring humans and some light-aligned creatures. They focus on luck manipulation and light magic - a magic 3 of the other factions are mostly weak to.Necropolis - a faction consisting of undead who compensate for their lack of morale buffs with the ability to revive fallen creatures using necromancy. They can be quite difficult to play, since they require you to have no losses what-so-ever to excel, but once you get hold of their penultimate building you can revive ALL fallen creatures from your former battles...providing your economy is strong enough.Inferno - a bunch of demons zerg rushing across the field. They die a lot. That's pretty much it.Stronghold - a faction of orcs, focusing on rushing and trolling the enemy. For example, goblins can put invisible traps on the battlefield, maulers get stronger if they are attacked, harpies can attack then fly away, centaurs shoot reaction shots when your opponent move across the field, etc. Pretty damn fun.Sanctuary - my personal favourite faction, focused on fighting honorably, one-on-one, and also water magics. They have a mixture of tanky units, strong ranged units, an ability that provides extra tankiness to all units provided you fight honorably, a lot of units that debuff the enemy - debuffs your hero can specialize in enhancing and last, but not least, a freaking water spirit dragon as a penultimate creature that can, if played right, carry your entire army across the field in one turn.I have postponed the bad things about this game until here. The "bad things" have a name - Ubisoft. First of all, you require UPlay to play this game. I almost committed sepukku once I'd been forced to sign up, but I was able to pull through. Ubisoft are dead-set on becoming the new EA, hated by everyone for ruining games. Not only did Ubisoft pull away resources and personel from the development team, leaving them with less to work with on the same timeframe. Not only did Ubisoft sabotage the development of the campaign by handing in the script for the story way too late to the devs, but they're still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly enough to put "PAY FOR MORE DLC" in the ♥♥♥♥ing main menu! You know, the first thing you see after you've paid for the ♥♥♥♥ing thing! Furthermore, there's a stupid meta-system called "dynasty", which gives ALL of your heroes perks depending on global experience gathered because do you know what's fun in multiplayer strategy games? Starting with unequal circumstances because of arbitrary ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, that's what everyone wants!In short: a good game that could have been great if not for Ubisoft.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												Might & Magic: Heroes VI is a excellent installment in the series - it provides hours upon hours of turnbased fun. It features good graphics and sound effects, although you may run into troubles if you use the highest graphic settings while playing on a older PC.It features various, by now well-known factions and a story for each of them, combined with two independent DLCs which add actual content to the game.The only downside - aside of the ubisoft launcher, of course - that I could find was the leveling system. You earn experience for everything you do and so your account level up slowly. Very slowly. Although it requires you to use the Ubisoft-Launcher it is a good game; if you are a fan of turnbased games I can only recommend you this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												I am a sucker for turn based, cell based combat, and Might & Magic: Heroes VI has plenty of it. Possibly even too much, as I am feeling burnt out after playing this game for so long. But thankfully there is an option for quick combat where the computer almost instantly resolves the encounter for you, and does so very reasonably as well. Of course this is not available for boss battles, which is good since some of them are really quite well done (especially in the expansion packs).I played through all the story campaigns (including the ones in the expansion packs), and it took me 80 hours to get through them. I have no intention of touching the multiplayer or skrimish modes, I've had my fill of the 6th entry in the Might & Magic Heroes series and I am feeling very positive about buying the game.Despite it being somewhat barebones, I actually enjoyed the story. It has an interesting premise and it is presented from many different points of view. And as before, the continued story in the expansion packs is actually better. Most of the story is presented with voice acted walls of text and through cutscenes. But it is true that the characters do feel wooden and there is nothing special going on here graphically.Some of the missions do have a tendency to drag on, especially since the prevalent strategy seems to be to just build up your army until you have a bigger army than your opponent. This is sometimes avoided by placing time limits on the main quests. But you can't get away from the fact that most missions really are the same thing over and over again, start with one city, build up an army, conquer more cities, repeat until you win. While this is simplifying it greatly, and there is variation here (well made maps, many different types of units to fight against, some interesting side quests), that is the basic premise of most every mission.Sadly it would appear that this game was not especially well received among the fans of the Might & Magic Heroes series. But I have to say that it's probably my favourite one so far. It tries to change up the formula of the games and in my mind it succeeds well enough.I would really recommend it only to fans of this kind of gameplay, otherwise you're just going to get bored with the slow pace of the game. Thankfully I fit the description and I got plenty of enjoyment out of the game.7½ / 10

												Definitely recommend!I had almost zero problems getting into the game and when there was an issue, I just started the game file as an adminstrator (look on the game forum for help).  Any time Ubisoft updated their software, I'd have to do it.  No big deal really.I bought this game on sale with all of the DLC.  GREAT VALUE!!  With that being said, I've played HOMM 2-6 and this series did not dissapoint at all.  I very much enjoyed the smooth game play and great storyline.  I'm on my entire 2nd playthrough, this one on hard (trying to get some of those dynasty weapons to lvl 5).  I also like the Dynasty system et al.  It added another layer that was previously not there.  I like it alot.  My ONLY issue  is the order in which you play the main campaign.  It's shown from left to right with the Tutorial missions first and then the Necro followed by Haven, Sacntuary, Inferno, and Stronghold.   I believe the best way to play the main campaign is chronologically versus each faction.    I suppose that's a matter of opinion though.  Either way, it was still a blast to play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 3, 2015
												I usually don't write reviews. I usually don't feel very strongly about the games I play. They are games, I enjoy them to a certain degree, but that is about the extent of my emotional investment. Now that we have this personal tidbit out of the way, let me begin by saying that I honestly like the Heroes franchise, which includes even the current atrocity and the (for many fans, anyway) mediocre installment that went before it.That is, I would really like to enjoy this game, but for the life of me I can't. Not that it doesn't have some strong suits: The unit models are downright gorgeous, and watching them duke it out in a Heroes-style arena is quite enjoyable. I don't even mind the weak storyline, the presentation of which makes you want to pop some ecstacy (figuratively speaking, of course) just to stay awake. I don't even mind, and I honestly didn't expect much to begin with.What I do mind is the absolutely distasteful, punch-in-the-face, DRM-nightmare platform that Ubisoft ever so tactfully forces upon the player, who put down hard cash to begin with and is most likely eager to play. But wait (and, trust me, you will have to wait a lot if you play this game, but more on that later), first create an account with the fun-loving, family-good-time platform that is Uplay. Already, that dreadful feeling of regret is kreeping along my spine as I feast my eyes, for the very first time, on Uplay and what will from now on be my personal window into the game. I blink once, I blink twice, I try my hardest to ignore the plethora of pile upon pile of achievement, cosmetic-personalization, and fictional-monies/credit ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. I look only for two things: Activate offline mode and play.The game loads, finally, the main menu appears. Naturally, the game is played. Strangely, some options in the character window are greyed out. The cold sweats are creeping back in. Immediately, I shut down and look for articles that explain this so-called in-game dynasty (not that it requires rocket science).Within minutes, it becomes painfully obvious that, should you choose or want to play the game offline, you're basically looking at a crippled product. Only if you connect to your account are you allowed to choose boni, with which your alter ego begins their adventure, dynasty weapons, pets, and custom heroes (otherwise, the one provided has to do). And, while it is true that these are mere boni, which add to, but are not strictly required in order to finish the game, you're always reminded how you may miss out whenever you find a new dynasty weapon or similar. (It is here I believe Ubisoft's lack of publishing talent is wasted on the gaming industry. They might want to consider psychological warfare.) Best of all, however,  if you wish to reset your progress, you're♥♥♥♥♥♥out of luck: What you do online, stays, at least until Ubisoft goes out of business. Above, I mentioned that your patience will be tested by this game, and it is true. Virtually every minute, you will be greeted by a loading screen. You start the game -- loading screen, you load a save -- loading screen (so far, so normal). The loading screen will stare at you for what will soon become an eternity. You are prompted to press any key to continue. You are now in the game world, but, lo and behold, certain items are missing -- such as your character, or other characters, or flags, or anything animated, really, because these are loaded on the fly after the loading screen (sick of the word "load", yet?) You enter your town, haven, or whatever you want to call it, and the screen says "Loading ..." for a bit. You enter battle, and the screen goes black (loading the battle scene, I presume), and sometimes the scene doesn't load at all. This happens before about 5 % to 10 % of all battles, thusly crashing the game. I cannot quite remember if Uplay attempts to synchronize your saves (a "feature", which can be turned off, fortunately), but when it does, know that you will stare at your screen for 2 to 5 minutes during synchronization.All this being said, I almost pity the developer for having to work under the yoke of Ubisoft and did not (it seems to me) have the opportunity to realize the full potential of the game -- even after the many patches.At any rate, Heroes VI will definitely be the last game I bought that has the Ubisoft sticker on it.

												Might an magic heros feels like a game that feels and plays very well. The art style is amazing. The combat is different but has it's ups and downs.  The story is a bit rough around the edges but..... wait.... I lost!? How can that be?! I just desimated his armies twice! How did he get an army twice my size under those conditions?! number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 12, 2015
												I am a sucker for turn based, cell based combat, and Might & Magic: Heroes VI has plenty of it. Possibly even too much, as I am feeling burnt out after playing this game for so long. But thankfully there is an option for quick combat where the computer almost instantly resolves the encounter for you, and does so very reasonably as well. Of course this is not available for boss battles, which is good since some of them are really quite well done (especially in the expansion packs).I played through all the story campaigns (including the ones in the expansion packs), and it took me 80 hours to get through them. I have no intention of touching the multiplayer or skrimish modes, I've had my fill of the 6th entry in the Might & Magic Heroes series and I am feeling very positive about buying the game.Despite it being somewhat barebones, I actually enjoyed the story. It has an interesting premise and it is presented from many different points of view. And as before, the continued story in the expansion packs is actually better. Most of the story is presented with voice acted walls of text and through cutscenes. But it is true that the characters do feel wooden and there is nothing special going on here graphically.Some of the missions do have a tendency to drag on, especially since the prevalent strategy seems to be to just build up your army until you have a bigger army than your opponent. This is sometimes avoided by placing time limits on the main quests. But you can't get away from the fact that most missions really are the same thing over and over again, start with one city, build up an army, conquer more cities, repeat until you win. While this is simplifying it greatly, and there is variation here (well made maps, many different types of units to fight against, some interesting side quests), that is the basic premise of most every mission.Sadly it would appear that this game was not especially well received among the fans of the Might & Magic Heroes series. But I have to say that it's probably my favourite one so far. It tries to change up the formula of the games and in my mind it succeeds well enough.I would really recommend it only to fans of this kind of gameplay, otherwise you're just going to get bored with the slow pace of the game. Thankfully I fit the description and I got plenty of enjoyment out of the game.7½ / 10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Being an avid fan of this type of turn-based strategy and having followed the series since its Kings Bounty origins, I had high hopes for this game. There are a couple of fundamental flaws that absolutely ruin the experience for me.First, this game has to be played on Ubisoft's UPlay network. If you cannot connect to UPlay, you cannot play the game. Being that the game would constantly error out when trying to connect to UPlay for the first time, as you can imagine, I was none to happy. Having your first interaction with a game be digging through support forums to launch an element that I will never use started me off on the wrong foot.At some point, I was able to find a work-around and get the game up-and-running, and being that every other Heroes game I've played was enjoyable, I was fine overlooking my initial mishap. Game had loaded, cinematic intro had played, and I was off and running on the tutorial. Much to my surprise, in my first battle, the melee troops reached my archers by the middle of the second round of combat even with my other melee troops occupying the board in front of my archers. I quickly came to the realization that they did not include zone-of-control in the combat system which was the nail in the coffin for me. In previous versions of the game, you could position melee troops to prevent your ranged troops from being immediately overrun by the opposing army. This was done using zone-of-control which would require an opposing melee troop to stop their movement if moving into an adjacent space to your troops. This helped create a buffer against the opposing team since the AI is programmed to go directly for your ranged troops first. Without this feature, the opposing army moves past your defenses every time, and there is no reasonable way to avoid heavy losses, especially when the battles get tougher.I’d be happy to overturn my opinion on this game if they can fix the zone-of-control problem, but as is and especially for those familiar with the series, I highly recommend looking elsewhere and saving yourself hours of frustration.

												I saw this game got a mixed review, and honestly i do not understand why.Surely you have to be online to play + the uplay client. And? This seems to be the source of many negative reviews. I find this strange since it is not that hard to log in to another client. But lets talk about the game instead:+ Really nice graphics, especially in the Haven and Sanctuary campaing, in my opinion those waterfalls and flooded areas are trully beautiful. + As far as i remember there were some earlygame imbalances but they got fixed by patches so now the game is really balanced creaturewise. + Good ingame music.+ The campaign was really good. Finally not a linear story where you unlock the next campaign by finishing the previous one. The stories happen at the same time so i highly recommend to look up the order the chapters are played out since it gives an extra epic feeling that the whole of Ashan is involved. The campaigns intertwine so it is possible to not understand the story if you just complete one campaign and then start another.Honestly the only negative thing about this game is that sometimes you can feel that the computer "cheats". Gets out too many units from too few castles. Oh and maybe that the magic trait heroes are a bit superior to the might heroes.  :)All in all i had a lot of fun with this game, i recommend it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Whether you play one of the campaigns, a one-off game, or a multiplayer match, you must choose from one of the five factions. Each faction has a different town in which it can construct unique buildings and recruit seven faction-specific creature types. The medieval Haven, hellish Inferno, and ghoulish Necropolis factions will be instantly familiar to veterans of the series, as might the snarling Stronghold faction introduced in Heroes of Might and Magic V: Tribes of the East. The Sanctuary faction, on the other hand, is entirely new and makes a great addition to the existing roster. The blue and green temples of a Sanctuary town feature the curved eaves of Japanese pagodas and sit atop flowing waterfalls. The creatures also draw on Eastern inspiration, including slithering, four-armed samurais (kenseis) and ethereal, kimono-clad water spirits (snow maidens).

content:
Posted: September 23, 2015
												To all those reviews about Yplay must always be online in order to play. It has an offline mode like steam does and it works fine. Yes you must redownload Uplay from Ubisoft, because the Uplay Version of the game doesn't work, but that is a minor thing. Heroes 6 is a great game. You can compare it to Homm3 or Homm5, but why would you do  that? You don't want to play the exact same game with new graphics. You want a new game with similar mechanics and same theme, but still we want some innovation. I like how your actions determine if your hero turns good or evil. Also the models and graphics are really good. The interface is very appealing and I like how you have a vast variety of skills to choose from for your hero. (a better system then Homm3 or Homm5)But what I like the most is, that you can now convert Dwellings into your own (as well can the enemy). That means exploring the world and finding any kind of Dwellings is very important and fun, Also guariding the Dwellings is now a considerable actions. (something I never did in the previous installment).Well I'm still at the beginning, but it looks like it is a worthy successor for Heroes of might and magic.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												The game itself is pretty good.It consists of economy management and tactical turn-based combat, using either of five factions who are fun to play but not always very well balanced against each other. You are in control of one or more heroes, who level up after winning enough combats with your army, learning new skills and what-not to use in the following combats. You construct buildings in your towns to recruit soldiers or give other benefits, and you'll soon find out that you're always in the lacks of blood crystals, inciting your continuous exploration. A collecting of sometimes murderously challenging campaigns (at least one for each faction) makes you fine-tune your strategy. This is all pretty damn fun.The factions:Haven - the boring faction consisting of boring humans and some light-aligned creatures. They focus on luck manipulation and light magic - a magic 3 of the other factions are mostly weak to.Necropolis - a faction consisting of undead who compensate for their lack of morale buffs with the ability to revive fallen creatures using necromancy. They can be quite difficult to play, since they require you to have no losses what-so-ever to excel, but once you get hold of their penultimate building you can revive ALL fallen creatures from your former battles...providing your economy is strong enough.Inferno - a bunch of demons zerg rushing across the field. They die a lot. That's pretty much it.Stronghold - a faction of orcs, focusing on rushing and trolling the enemy. For example, goblins can put invisible traps on the battlefield, maulers get stronger if they are attacked, harpies can attack then fly away, centaurs shoot reaction shots when your opponent move across the field, etc. Pretty damn fun.Sanctuary - my personal favourite faction, focused on fighting honorably, one-on-one, and also water magics. They have a mixture of tanky units, strong ranged units, an ability that provides extra tankiness to all units provided you fight honorably, a lot of units that debuff the enemy - debuffs your hero can specialize in enhancing and last, but not least, a freaking water spirit dragon as a penultimate creature that can, if played right, carry your entire army across the field in one turn.I have postponed the bad things about this game until here. The "bad things" have a name - Ubisoft. First of all, you require UPlay to play this game. I almost committed sepukku once I'd been forced to sign up, but I was able to pull through. Ubisoft are dead-set on becoming the new EA, hated by everyone for ruining games. Not only did Ubisoft pull away resources and personel from the development team, leaving them with less to work with on the same timeframe. Not only did Ubisoft sabotage the development of the campaign by handing in the script for the story way too late to the devs, but they're still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly enough to put "PAY FOR MORE DLC" in the ♥♥♥♥ing main menu! You know, the first thing you see after you've paid for the ♥♥♥♥ing thing! Furthermore, there's a stupid meta-system called "dynasty", which gives ALL of your heroes perks depending on global experience gathered because do you know what's fun in multiplayer strategy games? Starting with unequal circumstances because of arbitrary ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, that's what everyone wants!In short: a good game that could have been great if not for Ubisoft.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Honestly this game annoys me heavily on story and gameplay elements, least in the campaign.I played to just the second level so far, where the masoleum you captured is now your home base. Apparently your lead is such a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that he has lost....3-4 towns and not even realized it along with orcs dying, orcs you never actually get to see for more then just cut sceens and a very very very tiny group that joins you. Yet the orc ally won't shut the hell up, and is supposedly there and helping you yet never actually is, no reinforcments etc. From the get go your town is limited so much, that you can't even get the second level of troops for more then one type, meaning the rest troops are okay to just plainly just bad. To get the sisters to half way decent, you have to conquer a town that makes absolutely no sense why.For this town in question, you have a cut sceen where the ghost ancestor is fighting wolf troops, they win of course and you are right there, both teams in the open, out of cut sceen the ancestor is back snuggly within a town locked behind walls. After you beat him, instead of you being cool or anything your mom (reagent) comes by for ten seconds, sends the ancestor on his way, and guess what, she ditches your♥♥♥♥♥ no troops, no real reward. At this point in the game I have 40k+ gold because I literally can't spend it on anything and over 100 of each type of material. I can't hire troops either, since I have to wait for a week, just to be able to recruit, that means no mercenaries for hire (that might happen later in game)But my point is, this game is horribly paced, unbalanced, and just...bland the events in it are often criss crossing and have no rhym or reason. Oh and for the alignment system...it has more to do with your spells and such, then how you actually are. So once again limiting you down heavily.In short, this is more like a really bad jrpg then a heroes of might and magic game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Heroes VI is a difficult game to review. Does it stack up to previous HOMM games? Definitely not, this is a simplified version of what we have come to love. There are less resources and much less micro management in terms of obtaining the correct resources and even spells. If you still fire up HOMM 3 every now and then this wont even seem like the same game. And that is exactly how you have to treat it, as a different game and then you can see some of its merits. There is fun to be had in this game. The creatures are well thought out and the battles are satisfying. This is without a doubt the worst HOMM game but if it is on sale it is worth it if you are looking for a less intense HOMM session that generally will be a much shorter game.I also have to mention the performance of the game, it is very very poorly optimised and will struggle to produce decent framerates even on a high end computer. When it was launched, it was loaded with game breaking bugs, but for the most part these have been fixed. HOMM VI is a game I do recommend but with a very large asterisk next to it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												A must for tactical games enthusiasts with hardcore RPG elements. Deep characters, extremely detailed world and packed with heaps of lore and fantasy elements. The colors are extremely vivid and just outright gorgeous, probably the prettiest colors I've seen in a PC game so far. The soundtrack was beautifully crafted, being very pleasant to the ear and fitting to the game's atmosphere at all times. Online play is quite satisfactory and will keep you interested along with the game's already massive natural appeal in it's own right. If you liked games like Warcraft 3 and enjoys turn-based strategy you can't go wrong with this game, it's one of the finest blends of such genres so far, you'll find it's gameplay quite unique.I suggest buying the complete version, as it is much, much cheaper than buying the standalone expansions afterwards. You won't regret it!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 22, 2013
												This game has had quite a mixed reception among throughout the HOMM community and i really am at quite a loss to explain why. One way of filtering out the unjust negativity though is to ignore the near endless "not as good as HOMM3" comments as there are simply too many people who will always say this no matter what features the next HOMM game brings. This title intoduces several new features over it's predecessors, most notably the dynasty weapons, traits and heroes, which are saved and can be used in any skirmish game once unlocked. Graphically it is the best version of HOMM by far and while there are many new features that debut in this title, the core gameplay allows anyone familiar with the HOMM series to get stuck in immediately. The game does suffer from the occasional graphics glitch and the campaign is extremely unforgiving at times, but these flaws do not sour the experience at all. This IS the best HOMM title to date.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Ok..so this is the first time I actually decided to give my opinion on a purchase. Frankly i'm kinda amazed at all the negative comments. But to be fair I just have not encountered ANY of the issues others are complaining about. Keep in mind Ive only played it for about 3 hours. YES... the game does need UPlay to run. If this an issue for you do not buy it. To me it is no big deal. However they SHOULD put that in the Description so people that this is an issue for KNOW it before the purchase.THat being said...I haven't played the Might and Magic series since it was on 3.5 disks. I just remember that i really enjoyed playing the game so I decided to try this one. I only paid 7.50 for it so i figured no biggie if i didn't like it. But so far i LOVE IT. The installation went flawlessly...and since i already had a U-Play account that part of it was also seamless and i had ZERO issues launching the game after installation. When it asks for the CD Key you need to put in the KEY for the Main game ONLY. The DLC codes are updated automatically I assume since I never had to put them in but they are available from the beginning. As far as bad acting goes...(voicovers) umm really ??? that matters to people ??? Oh well I guess i am just to interested in Gameplay ...not so much on dialog...especially in a game like this. Now if it was a survival horror or fantasy first person rpg where story is super important for atmosphere or moving the story along then yeah Dialog and acting is important but for this particular game ehh!!!Graphics are great and gameplay is simple even if you have NEVER played a Might and Magic game before. I am running an old duo core amd 3.2 CPU with 8 GB ram and a Radeaon 4650  with 1gb ram and have zero issues so far with crashes or lock ups. THe game runs smooth and looks amazing compared to the older M&M games that I remember. As far as the other issues that some of the more experienced M&M players have talked about I just have not had any yet. Over all I think this a great game for those of us that like Turn Based as opposed to Real Time strategy games and i would recommend it (WHILE IT IS ON SALE) to anyone that is into Turn Based Fantasy Stategy games. That is my humble opinion and EVERYONE is entitled to MY opinion!!!  :) Peace

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Whether you play one of the campaigns, a one-off game, or a multiplayer match, you must choose from one of the five factions. Each faction has a different town in which it can construct unique buildings and recruit seven faction-specific creature types. The medieval Haven, hellish Inferno, and ghoulish Necropolis factions will be instantly familiar to veterans of the series, as might the snarling Stronghold faction introduced in Heroes of Might and Magic V: Tribes of the East. The Sanctuary faction, on the other hand, is entirely new and makes a great addition to the existing roster. The blue and green temples of a Sanctuary town feature the curved eaves of Japanese pagodas and sit atop flowing waterfalls. The creatures also draw on Eastern inspiration, including slithering, four-armed samurais (kenseis) and ethereal, kimono-clad water spirits (snow maidens).

Posted: May 26, 2015
												Might & Magic: Heroes VI is a excellent installment in the series - it provides hours upon hours of turnbased fun. It features good graphics and sound effects, although you may run into troubles if you use the highest graphic settings while playing on a older PC.It features various, by now well-known factions and a story for each of them, combined with two independent DLCs which add actual content to the game.The only downside - aside of the ubisoft launcher, of course - that I could find was the leveling system. You earn experience for everything you do and so your account level up slowly. Very slowly. Although it requires you to use the Ubisoft-Launcher it is a good game; if you are a fan of turnbased games I can only recommend you this game.

content:
Posted: July 16, 2012
												Heroes 6 can be described as massive. It could also be described as tedious and arbitary. The size of this game is colossal. There is so much to do and to customise, it is hard to know where to start. The turnside of this is that it is hard to come to grips with, and slow. The game offers you deep strategic gameplay and character building, but progress is slow and enemies grow too powerful too fast. Which leads to tedious grinding and almost boring gameplay which was exicting a turn earlier. But none of this troubles you when you are immersed in this grand and excellent experience of top notch rpg tactic. And that is the problem, you cannot get immersed because of Ubisofts ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ DRM. You'll spend more time trying to get the save files synched than actually playing. Actually getting the game to work merits an achievement cause you need to verify so many codes and agreements it's almost unheard of. Honestly, the game itself is terrific, but the included shackles are very stifling.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2013
												An extremely fun and well-crafted combination of RPG and turn-based strategy. Adventure and level up with your Heroes - earning skills, spells, and items along the way... but also engage in complex combat sequences of turn-based strategy - involving armies of various units (with various characteristics and abilities) on an isometric grid, similar to a large chess board.Imagine Warcraft (the original RTS games) but everything is turn-based and combat occurs on the "chess-board" screens. You have bases (cities and forts), you collect resources with mines, lumber mills, etc, and you buy new units as time goes on.Warning: the game is a bit buggy, including a few game-breaking bugs that are best avoided if possible (check forums if you are concerned. But Ubisoft is continuously patching these bugs... or so they say, anyway.Still, very fun game, I've already put 200+ hours into it in a couple weeks, and I've barely scratched the surface of the various single player campaigns and mutiplayer options. I recommend it to any RPG and/or strategy fans.

												Better then 5, Leaps and bounds better than 4, but not better then 3. Lets face it, 3 was the apex of this series. It could have been as good as 3, it had the same feel to it. The only thing that it lacked, the only thing that held it back was a simple AUTO BATTLE button. You have to fight every single battle there is. You could have an army that would shake the world in this game, but up against some creature gaurding something that doestn run or surrender, even though there is ony like 10 of them, you have to fight. Making small, non significant battles, where you know you are going to win 100% because you have 300 dragons vs 50 Gosh Darn Sprites, You have to play it. taking 3-4 min of your time to beat something that you should be able to say to the game "Auto solve this for me will ya!" If it wasnt for that, it would have lived up to its older brother 3. That pitfall makes the game feel tidious and lackluster. 6/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
												Heroes of Might and Magic III is an all-time great. It remains the perfect game, the pinnacle of the series and one of the best turn-based strategy games. Devotees have been awaiting the series return to this mark but sadly, each subsequent game has fallen short. The latest entry, Might & Magic: Heroes VI, further distanced the series from its former accolades and remains the worst of the version yet.Revising the word direction from Heroes of Might and Magic to Might & Magic: Heroes is a minor, albeit odd change and representative of Ubisoft’s apparent disdain of the series’ history, which was formerly known as HOMM.The graphics have improved, but this style of game was never about the graphics.One of the biggest changes is the opening up all heroes for hire from the start. There is no longer the choice of two random heroes at the tavern. You can scroll through the entire cast and pick whomever you want. The hero change does not end there in that you can pick any skill upon level up. These two changes considerably change the game for the worse. It was a fun trademark of Homm to check your two each week to see what heroes were available. This eliminates a sense of randomness and uniqueness that each game held in the past. It also leads a player to pick their favorite hero each game rather than being faced with the decision to choose between two random heroes. Additionally, classic level ups required careful decision, with a bit of luck, to pick the best skills for your play style. The changes in Heroes VI eliminate those gameplay mechanics and ultimately decrease the fun of the game.The resources have also been scaled back to just gold, wood, ore and crystals. This is another change that eliminates critical components of the core game. Managing resources, picking up piles and fighting for mines were a fun part of the original games. The mines are also tied to castles now and you cannot control them over until you take the town. This is ridiculous and eliminates the ability to cutoff an opponent’s supply lines if said opponent decides to stay and defend in town. This was another component of the old game that has been removed. You could choose to go straight for a town and affect a brute force finish or choose to slowly buildup, control the map and hamper your opponent’s production. This is another choice eliminated from the game.What remains is no longer the core Heroes games. Choice is eliminated and it has become incredibly linear. This is not the Heroes I remember or wish to play.One strength of HOMM3 was the random map generator, which excelled at creating balanced maps and gave the game an unprecedented level of replayability. This feature has not returned and the offering of maps in Heroes VI is laughably slim. This game is severely lacking in actual content. One of the only quantifiable additions is Ubisoft's inclusion of its atrocious UPLAY software, which you are forced to install and suffer with.Ubisoft just does not get it. They are hard at work on part seven and it looks much the same as part six. They are holding votes to pick which factions you would like to see in the end game. This false sense of choice is insulting. A better service would be to over deliver and provide all of the towns they have conceived. Part seven, like six is shaping up to have less content, less options, less variety and much less replayability than a game that was released in the 90s. This series would be better served by being retired rather than being revised for another bi-annual cash grab.

Posted: July 15, 2013
												I have not beaten this one yet, but I did play a heck of a lot of Heros III, and this is a major improvement on that title. The animations or each creature are really detailed and I'm a huge sucker for voice-acting, but they even have voice-scripted narrative too.  And so far I really like the narrative.  My only beef with this game is really just Uplay. You have to create a Uplay account before you can play the game, and it's not entirely intuitive what key they want.  You'll figure it out eventually though. This is a big improvement on the Heros of M&M series and I officially reccomend it for those people who like turn-based combat/strategy games.
